question: Is this patient suitable for clear aligner treatment?
synonyms: Am I a candidate for clear aligners?
Which patients are good aligner cases?
Who should I treat with aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Patient suitability for clear aligner therapy depends mainly on case complexity, compliance, and oral health. Aligners are very effective in the right context, but not every patient is an ideal candidate.
Case complexity ‚Äì Mild to moderate crowding, spacing, and Class I malocclusions are highly predictable. Severe skeletal discrepancies, vertical issues, or complex root movements are less reliable with aligners alone.
Compliance ‚Äì Aligners require 20‚Äì22 hours/day wear. Poor compliance is one of the most common reasons for treatment failure.
Oral health ‚Äì Patients must have a stable periodontium and good hygiene. Untreated caries or active periodontal disease are contraindications until addressed.
Referral threshold ‚Äì Severe skeletal discrepancies or highly complex movements (e.g. large rotations, posterior intrusion) may require referral, auxiliaries, or interdisciplinary treatment.
üëâ Helle-note: If you are unsure whether to start, choose straightforward cases first. This builds your confidence and helps your patients see clear results. Complex cases can often be managed in collaboration with a specialist.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q101
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can aligners correct deep bite cases?
synonyms: Can clear aligners treat overbite?
Are aligners effective for deep bite correction?
What is possible with aligners in vertical bite problems?
answer_markdown:
A. Clear aligners can be effective for deep bite correction, but predictability depends on whether the problem is dental or skeletal in nature.
Dental deep bites ‚Äì Often corrected by intruding incisors and/or extruding posteriors. Sometimes in combination with proclination of the anteriors. Attachments, bite ramps (for posterior extrusion), and careful staging improve predictability.
Skeletal deep bites ‚Äì Aligners alone cannot modify vertical skeletal growth. These cases may require orthognathic surgery or a multidisciplinary approach. In adults you have to consider whether¬†a compromise is acceptable or if surgery is need.
Staging considerations ‚Äì Intrusion/extrusion should be planned in small increments. Posterior intrusion is far less predictable; anterior intrusion up to 2 mm. can be effective. If you need more intrusion consider either using fixed appliances or combine the aligner treatment with TADs and proper auxiliaries.
Risk management ‚Äì Monitor closely. Control tracking, look out for root resorptions and ensure proper posterior occlusal stops for long-term stability.
üëâ Helle-note: Start with mild to moderate dental deep bite cases. For severe skeletal discrepancies, consider referring the patient or a compromise that will result in a stable functional occlusion with a long term retention strategy.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q102
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can aligners correct open bite cases?
synonyms: Are open bites treatable with aligners?
How predictable is open bite closure with aligners?
What is the best approach to aligner open bite cases?
answer_markdown:
A. Open bite correction with aligners is possible but can be challenging depending on etiology and severity.
Dental open bites ‚Äì Often caused by tongue habits or eruption patterns. Aligners can intrude posteriors (Difficult and time consuming) or extrude anteriors to help close the bite. Proper attachments, vertical elastics and sometimes TADs can increase predictability.
Skeletal open bites ‚Äì True skeletal open bites are much less predictable. They often require orthognathic surgery or a combined approach with skeletal anchorage.
Stability ‚Äì Relapse risk is high, especially if underlying habits (e.g. tongue thrust, thumb sucking) are not addressed. Long-term retention and habit control are essential.
Clinical tip ‚Äì A tongue habit is almost always part of the picture in open bite cases. Collaboration with a speech therapist is essential. Some orthodontists advocate correcting the tongue habit before starting orthodontic treatment, while others argue that adequate space must first be created for the tongue to adapt to a new function. We lean toward the latter approach: address the dental component first, then retrain the tongue to ensure long-term stability. As part of the dental phase, spikes can be incorporated into the aligners to discourage tongue thrusting and support habit modification.
üëâ Helle-note: Start with simple anterior open bite cases with clear dental causes. For complex skeletal open bites, plan for interdisciplinary collaboration and set realistic expectations with your patient.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH06:SEC07:open-bite

question: Can aligners correct Class II cases?
synonyms: Can clear aligners treat overjet?
Are aligners suitable for Class II correction?
How do you manage Class II malocclusion with aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners can help in Class II cases, but success depends on case selection and whether the discrepancy is skeletal or dental.
Dental Class II ‚Äì Mild to moderate cases with proclination/retroclination or small space discrepancies can often be corrected with distalisation, elastics, interproximal reduction or a combination.
Skeletal Class II ‚Äì Aligners cannot correct a skeletal discrepancy alone. Growth modification (in children/teens) or orthognathic surgery (in adults) may be required.
Adjuncts ‚Äì Class II elastics are frequently used with aligners, but compliance is critical. Precision cuts or buttons may be needed to apply elastic force.
Treatment goals ‚Äì Focus on improving function and esthetics within the biological limits of aligners, and communicate clearly with patients about realistic outcomes.
üëâ Helle-note: Start with mild dental Class II cases using elastics and staged distalisation. For skeletal discrepancies, involve a specialist early and manage expectations carefully.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q104
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: What are the limitations with severe crowding and periodontally compromised patients?
synonyms: Can aligners treat severe crowding?
What precautions with aligners in periodontal patients?
How much crowding is too much for aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Severe crowding and periodontal compromise both reduce predictability and demand careful treatment planning.
Severe crowding ‚Äì May exceed aligner capability without auxiliaries. Consider IPR and using auxiliaries or combining with fixed appliances. In the most severe situations, extractions may be required. Extraction cases should always be referred to an orthodontist.
Periodontal patients ‚Äì Orthodontic treatment is only safe in periodontally compromised patients if the disease is fully controlled and the tissues are stable.¬†Reduced bone support requires light, continuous forces and slower staging. Avoid aggressive expansion or proclination.
Monitoring ‚Äì Periodontal patients need strict recall intervals and close hygiene control.
Clinical judgement ‚Äì Balance esthetic demands with biological limits. In some cases, aligners may serve best for alignment after initial periodontal stabilisation.
üëâ Helle-note: Always start by stabilising periodontal health before any tooth movement. For severe crowding, consider whether aligners are the right tool, or if a combined approach with extractions or fixed appliances will better protect your patient.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH03:SEC15:spacing-and-crowding

question: Are aligners effective for rotating canines?
synonyms: Can aligners rotate canines?
How predictable are canine rotations with aligners?
What should I know about canine rotation cases?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners can rotate canines, but predictability is lower compared to other tooth movements. Rotational control of these teeth is considered one of the more challenging movements in aligner therapy.
Biomechanical challenge ‚Äì Canines have large, conical roots and strong periodontal support, making them more resistant to rotation.
Attachments ‚Äì Are always needed. We recommend conventional rectangular attachments to provide sufficient rotational couple. They must be well bonded and placed accurately to avoid aligner ‚Äúslippage.‚Äù
Force management ‚Äì For greater predictability, reduce movement speed to about 1¬∞ per aligner and limit rotations of the canines to a rotation only phase, rather than combining multiple movements of these teeth. Overcorrection, as sometimes used in fixed appliances, should not be relied upon in aligner therapy.
Monitoring ‚Äì Tracking problems are common. If rotation stalls, consider auxiliary methods (buttons + elastomerics or sectional fixed appliances) to regain control.
üëâ Helle-note: Expect that canine rotations will test your patience. Always use attachments and always monitor closely so you can intervene early if tracking is lost.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH04:SEC07:tooth-movements-definitions, MAO:TBD:q107
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can aligners correct posterior crossbite cases?
synonyms: Are aligners effective for posterior crossbite?
Can aligners expand the arch?
How predictable is crossbite correction with aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Posterior crossbites can sometimes be corrected with aligners, but predictability depends on age, etiology, and the amount of expansion required.
Dental crossbites ‚Äì Mild unilateral or bilateral posterior crossbites of dental origin can often be corrected with controlled expansion and buccal tipping.
Skeletal crossbites ‚Äì True skeletal crossbites cannot be corrected with aligners alone. In growing patients, rapid maxillary expansion is required; in adults, surgical assistance may be necessary.
Expansion limits ‚Äì Aligners provide tipping rather than bodily expansion. Over-expansion risks instability and relapse. Safe, predictable limits are usually 2‚Äì3 mm per side.
Adjuncts ‚Äì Cross elastics or hybrid appliances may be used to increase predictability. Long-term retention is critical to prevent relapse.
üëâ Helle-note: Choose only mild dental crossbite cases for aligners. Always be honest with patients about the limitations, and collaborate with orthodontists when skeletal expansion is required.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH06:SEC11:transversal-discrepancy

question: Are aligners effective for posterior open bite correction?
synonyms: Can aligners treat posterior open bite?
Why do posterior open bites happen with aligners?
How predictable is posterior open bite closure?
answer_markdown:
A. Posterior open bites are a relatively common finding during or after aligner treatment. They are often iatrogenic and may require specific strategies for correction.
Etiology ‚Äì Posterior open bites can result from over-eruption of anterior teeth, intrusion side effects, or occlusal interferences from aligner plastic.
Management ‚Äì Correction is unpredictable with aligners alone. Options include selective grinding of premature contacts, elastics, or refinements with adjusted staging.
Predictability limits ‚Äì Pure posterior extrusion with aligners is difficult to achieve. Often a hybrid approach or fixed appliances are needed if significant extrusion is required.
Prevention ‚Äì Careful monitoring of occlusion during treatment, including articulation paper checks, helps avoid posterior open bite development.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt panic if you encounter a posterior open bite. Often it can be managed with refinements or simple elastics, but remember that extrusion is not aligners‚Äô strongest movement. Be clear with your patient that sometimes hybrid mechanics are required.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q110
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can Class III patients be treated with aligners?
synonyms: Are aligners effective for underbite correction?
Can aligners treat Class III malocclusion?
What are the limits of aligners in Class III cases?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners can assist in selected Class III cases, but success depends entirely on whether the discrepancy is dental or skeletal.
Dental Class III ‚Äì Mild anterior crossbites or edge-to-edge cases may be corrected with limited proclination of upper incisors, retroclination of lower incisors, or mild expansion. These can be reasonable aligner cases when periodontal health and compliance are good.
Skeletal Class III ‚Äì True skeletal discrepancies cannot be corrected with aligners alone. In growing patients, orthopedic interventions (facemask, skeletal anchorage) may help. In adults, orthognathic surgery is usually required for meaningful correction.
Adjuncts ‚Äì Class III elastics, TADs, or hybrid appliances may be combined with aligners to manage dental components, but compliance is critical.
Functional considerations ‚Äì Interestingly, true skeletal Class III patients (not those with anterior displacement into a forced bite) are often quite forgiving in terms of functional occlusion. Many of them do not perform significant excursive movements, which reduces the need for canine guidance.
üëâ Helle-note: Use aligners for mild dental Class III cases, but don‚Äôt hesitate to involve a specialist when the skeletal discrepancy is obvious. This protects your patient from disappointment and safeguards you as the treating dentist.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH06:SEC10:class-iii

question: Are aligners effective for midline correction?
synonyms: Can aligners correct dental midlines?
How predictable is midline correction with aligners?
Can I use aligners for midline shifts?
answer_markdown:
A. Midline correction with aligners is possible, but predictability depends on the etiology, magnitude of shift, and available anchorage.
Dental midline shifts ‚Äì Small discrepancies (1‚Äì2 mm) due to minor crowding or spacing are often manageable with aligners.
Skeletal midline shifts ‚Äì Skeletal asymmetries cannot be corrected with aligners. These require orthopedic or surgical approaches.
Anchorage management ‚Äì Genuine midline correction is rarely achieved by simply pushing teeth around in one arch. It requires coordinated, reciprocal movement between the upper and lower arches. Depending on the case, this may involve the use of power arms, elastics, unilateral IPR, or carefully planned space closure. Without proper anchorage control, midline shifts often relapse or lead to unwanted side effects elsewhere in the arch.
Limits ‚Äì Larger shifts (>2 mm) are difficult to correct with aligners alone. Over-expansion or asymmetric movements risk instability or periodontal compromise.
üëâ Helle-note: Use aligners for small midline corrections only. Be clear with your patients that bigger shifts are not aligner territory, and plan for power arms, elastics or interdisciplinary input when things are more complex.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q112
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: When should I refer instead of treating myself?
synonyms: When is a case too complex for me?
Which aligner patients should be referred to a specialist?
How do I know if an aligner case is beyond my scope?
answer_markdown:
A. Deciding when to refer is just as important as knowing when to treat. Clear aligners have limits, and your own training and experience define where those limits lie in daily practice.
Skeletal discrepancies ‚Äì True skeletal Class II or III cases, transverse discrepancies, or vertical problems that cannot be camouflaged should be referred.
Severe bite problems ‚Äì Complex open bites, deep bites requiring significant intrusion/extrusion, or vertical control beyond 2‚Äì3 mm are often best managed in specialist hands.
Extraction cases ‚Äì Particularly multiple extractions, asymmetric space closure, or where root control is critical. These are among the least predictable aligner treatments. Even a lot of orthodontists have a lot of respect for any kind of extraction cases.
Personal competence ‚Äì If the biomechanics, staging, or use of auxiliaries are beyond your comfort zone, referral is the safest choice for both patient and clinician.
üëâ Helle-note: There is no weakness in referring. We are always ready to help. But if we sense that a dentist is inexperienced or not confident enough to handle a specific treatment safely, we will recommend referral to a more experienced colleague or an orthodontist. Patients value honesty and safety above all, and this builds long-term trust. Build confidence with straightforward cases first, and don‚Äôt hesitate to collaborate with a specialist for the complex ones.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q113
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can aligners manage skeletal malocclusions?
synonyms: Are aligners effective for skeletal discrepancies?
Can aligners fix jaw problems?
Do aligners work for Class II or III skeletal cases?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners alone cannot correct true skeletal malocclusions. Their effect is limited to dental compensation and camouflage. Significant skeletal corrections require growth modification in young patients or surgical intervention in adults.
Dental compensation ‚Äì Aligners can align teeth within the skeletal framework, often by proclining or retroclining incisors to reduce the visible discrepancy.
Growth modification ‚Äì In growing patients, functional appliances or orthopedic interventions are needed to alter jaw relationships. Aligners cannot provide this effect.
Surgical correction ‚Äì Adults with severe Class II, Class III, or vertical discrepancies often require orthognathic surgery. Aligners may be used before and after surgery to align teeth and coordinate arches.
Limits of camouflage ‚Äì Attempting to mask skeletal issues with excessive tooth movement risks instability, relapse, or compromised periodontal health.
üëâ Helle-note: Aligners are excellent tools for dental alignment, but they cannot change the jaws. If you see a true skeletal discrepancy, be upfront with your patient and involve an orthodontist or surgeon early in the planning.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q114
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Is unilateral/bilateral crossbite suitable for aligner treatment?
synonyms: Can aligners fix crossbites?
Are unilateral crossbites treatable with aligners?
How do you manage bilateral crossbite cases with aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Many crossbite cases can be corrected with aligners, but success depends on whether the discrepancy is dental or skeletal, as well as the amount of expansion required.
Dental crossbites ‚Äì Mild to moderate unilateral or bilateral posterior crossbites of dental origin are often treatable with controlled buccal tipping and arch coordination.
Skeletal crossbites ‚Äì Significant skeletal discrepancies cannot be corrected with aligners alone. In growing patients, orthopedic expansion is needed, while adults may require surgically assisted expansion.
Adjuncts ‚Äì Cross elastics or auxiliaries can improve predictability in dental crossbite cases.
Limits of expansion ‚Äì Aligners primarily tip teeth rather than bodily expand the arch. Safe expansion is typically limited to 2‚Äì3 mm per side. Over-expansion risks instability and relapse.
üëâ Helle-note: Aligners work well for mild dental crossbites, especially when combined with elastics. But be realistic ‚Äì true skeletal crossbites usually require an orthodontist and sometimes surgery.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH06:SEC11:transversal-discrepancy

question: How do I assess patient compliance potential?
synonyms: How can I tell if my patient will wear aligners enough?
How do I know if compliance will be good?
What are signs of poor aligner compliance?
answer_markdown:
A. Assessing compliance potential is critical for aligner success. Even the best treatment plan fails if aligners are not worn as prescribed.
Daily habits ‚Äì Ask about work, school, and social routines. Patients who snack frequently, travel often, or have irregular schedules may struggle with consistent wear.
Motivation ‚Äì Explore the patient‚Äôs personal reasons for wanting treatment (aesthetic vs functional). Higher motivation usually correlates with better compliance.
Past behaviour ‚Äì Patients with a history of poor compliance in dental care (missed appointments, poor hygiene, or failed retainer wear) may require closer monitoring.
Support system ‚Äì In younger patients, parental involvement is a strong predictor of good compliance. Adults may benefit from digital reminders or more frequent check-ins.
üëâ Helle-note: Always be upfront‚Äîaligners only work if they‚Äôre worn. If you suspect compliance will be poor, plan for extra monitoring or consider alternative treatment options.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q116
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Which photos are absolutely required?
synonyms: What clinical photos do I need for aligner submission?
Which intraoral and extraoral photos are mandatory?
Do I need occlusal and profile images for aligner treatment?
answer_markdown:
A. High-quality clinical photos are essential for diagnosis, treatment planning, and communication with the aligner company. At minimum, both intraoral and extraoral standards must be met.
Intraoral ‚Äì Frontal, right and left buccal, maxillary occlusal, and mandibular occlusal views. These document tooth positions, arch form, and occlusion.
Extraoral ‚Äì Frontal (natural smile and at rest) and profile (right or left) views. These are among the most important records for orthodontic treatment planning, as they determine how tooth movements will affect soft tissue and the overall appearance of the lower face.
Technical quality ‚Äì Photos should be well-lit, in focus, and properly framed. Use cheek retractors and mirrors for occlusal views.
Why it matters ‚Äì Complete photo sets are an absolute necessity for treatment planning, reduce setup errors, improve communication with technicians, and support medico-legal documentation.
Not a substitute ‚Äì Screenshots of intraoral scans are not acceptable as replacements for clinical photos. Scans do not show biological conditions clearly, they fail to capture soft tissues properly, and they don‚Äôt allow double-checking of occlusion in the digital setup. If the occlusion is wrong from the start, the whole plan fails, no matter how well it‚Äôs staged.
üëâ Helle-note: Always take the full standard set of photos. It saves time, prevents miscommunication, and gives you the best foundation for treatment planning. Patients also appreciate seeing their ‚Äúbefore‚Äù pictures when you review progress later. You can find our full step-by-step photo protocol here: https://www.alignerservice.com/photo-protokol Need to improve your photographic skills? Check out our free online course: https://www.alignerservice.com/challenge-page/e27957b7-8a46-4892-92aa-2017676015eb?programId=e27957b7-8a46-4892-92aa-2017676015eb

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q211
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Do I always need x-rays?
synonyms: Are x-rays mandatory for aligner treatment?
Which radiographs are required before starting aligners?
Do I need a CBCT for every aligner patient?
answer_markdown:
A. Radiographs are an essential part of orthodontic diagnostics, but the type of x-rays needed depends on the case.
Panoramic x-ray (OPG) ‚Äì Commonly recommended as a baseline record. It shows root morphology, bone levels, tooth eruption, and pathology. This helps detect conditions that could complicate aligner treatment (impactions, cysts, root resorption, periodontal problems).
Lateral cephalometric x-ray ‚Äì Useful for assessing skeletal relationships, growth patterns, and treatment planning in more complex malocclusions. Always needed when treating children and surgical cases. Rarely required in straightforward adult cases.
CBCT ‚Äì Reserved for specific indications such as impacted teeth, TMJ pathology, airway analysis, or surgical planning. It should not be used routinely due to higher radiation exposure.
Many aligner companies now offer features that visualise how teeth will move ‚Äúwithin the bone‚Äù based on CBCT data. However, these are graphic simulations, generated by software that interprets radiographic data, not true biological remodelling.
Because bone remodelling cannot be predicted or simulated, these visualisations should never be used as the basis for clinical decisions or treatment planning. They are ‚Äúnice-to-have‚Äù images, not a clinical necessity.
In fact, such features may risk under- or over-diagnosing the consequences of tooth movements, potentially leading to mistreatment of patients.
Based on Jesper Hatt‚Äôs experience as an international Key Opinion Leader for KaVo in CBCT, combined with our insight into aligner software, we cannot currently recommend the integration of CBCT visualisations into aligner treatment planning.
Principle of ALARA ‚Äì Always follow ‚ÄúAs Low As Reasonably Achievable.‚Äù Only take the x-rays needed to safely diagnose and plan treatment.
üëâ Helle-note: A panoramic x-ray is your safest baseline record‚Äîit often reveals surprises you can‚Äôt see clinically. Use cephs and CBCTs when the case truly demands it, but don‚Äôt expose patients unnecessarily.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q212
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: How do I avoid scanning errors, including bite registration?
synonyms: How can I get accurate intraoral scans?
What causes bite registration errors in IO scans?
How do I make sure my scan matches the patient‚Äôs occlusion?
answer_markdown:
A. Accurate intraoral scans are essential for predictable aligner treatment. Errors in scan capture or bite registration can compromise the entire digital setup and lead to poor clinical outcomes.
Full arch capture ‚Äì Always include all of the most distal molars in both arches. Missing distal anatomy causes poor articulation and inaccurate aligner fit. If third molars are present they can be hard to scan. In these cases, make sure to capture at least half of the tooth surface (the mesial part). This ensures the aligner will cover half the occlusal surface and prevent elongation during treatment.
Midline verification ‚Äì Check that the dental midlines match intraorally and digitally. A shifted bite scan can lead to a completely incorrect occlusal relationship in the virtual plan.
Bite registration ‚Äì Use habitual intercuspation for most cases, and scan buccal bite registrations on both sides. Centric relation (CR) registration can be performed under specific conditions, but remember: aligner software is not an articulator. You cannot rely on a so-called ‚Äúbite jump‚Äù if it appears digitally.
Managing CR vs MIP discrepancies ‚Äì There are several clinical approaches to deal with discrepancies between CR and MIP. These are described in detail in our book Mastering Aligner Orthodontics, available here: https://www.alignerservice.com/shop
Quality control ‚Äì Inspect scans for holes, overlaps, or stitching errors. Rescan areas of poor data capture before submission.
Clinical consequence ‚Äì If the bite is wrong at the start, the whole plan will be wrong, no matter how well it is staged.
üëâ Helle-note: Take your time with scanning‚Äîit‚Äôs the foundation of everything that follows. Always double-check occlusion before you submit, because fixing a scanning error later costs both you and your patient unnecessary time and frustration.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q213
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Are PVS impressions still acceptable for aligners?
synonyms: Can I send impressions instead of scans?
Are PVS impressions accurate enough for aligner cases?
Do aligner companies still accept silicone impressions?
answer_markdown:
A. Most aligner systems now prefer intraoral scans, but high-quality PVS impressions are still accepted by many companies. The key is that impressions must be taken and handled with great precision to avoid distortions.
Accuracy ‚Äì IO-scans generally provide superior accuracy, especially for occlusion and distal molar capture. PVS impressions risk distortion during removal, pouring, or shipping.
Acceptance ‚Äì Some aligner companies still accept PVS, but many are shifting toward a ‚Äúscan only‚Äù model. Always check current submission guidelines.
Clinical workflow ‚Äì Digital scans integrate directly into software, speeding up turnaround time and reducing errors. Impressions add extra steps (pouring, scanning at the lab).
When to use PVS ‚Äì Only if IO-scanning is unavailable. Use heavy/light body silicone with full-arch trays, ensure distal capture, and check for voids before sending.
üëâ Helle-note: While impressions can still work, our experience from more than 35,000 treatment plans shows a very clear trend‚Äîtreatments run smoother and require fewer refinements when scans are used. Aligners simply fit better, and patients experience fewer sore spots on the mucosa and less tongue irritation. If you must take PVS, be meticulous‚Äîit‚Äôs your patient‚Äôs treatment plan that depends on it.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q214
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: What if the scan doesn‚Äôt upload properly?
synonyms: Why is my scan upload failing?
How do I fix errors when uploading scans?
What should I do if the scanner won‚Äôt send files?
answer_markdown:
A. Upload errors are common technical issues, but they can usually be resolved with a systematic check of the workflow.
Internet connection ‚Äì Confirm that you have a stable internet connection. Interrupted uploads often stem from weak Wi-Fi signals.
Scanner software ‚Äì Ensure your scanner software is up to date. Outdated versions may not be compatible with the aligner company‚Äôs platform.
File format ‚Äì Verify that the file is in the accepted format (usually STL, PLY, or proprietary format depending on the system).
Re-upload ‚Äì If the file seems corrupted or stuck in processing, restart the scanner software and re-upload the case.
Support ‚Äì If problems persist, contact the scanner provider or aligner company‚Äôs technical support team for troubleshooting.
üëâ Helle-note: Upload problems are frustrating, but don‚Äôt panic. Take a step-by-step approach‚Äîmost often it‚Äôs a simple connectivity or update issue. If in doubt, reach out early for support so your patient‚Äôs case isn‚Äôt delayed.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q215
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Are intraoral photos mandatory?
synonyms: Do I really need to take intraoral photos?
Can aligner cases be submitted without photos?
Why are intraoral photos important for aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes. Intraoral photos are mandatory for proper diagnosis, treatment planning, and effective communication with technicians. They provide critical details that scans alone cannot capture.
Diagnosis ‚Äì Intraoral photos document caries, periodontal health, wear facets, and tissue conditions not visible on scans.
Documentation ‚Äì They create a medico-legal record of the patient‚Äôs initial condition and progress over time.
Communication ‚Äì Photos help aligner technicians and online treatment planners like AlignerService.com to understand the case context, improving the quality of the digital setup.
Limitations of scans ‚Äì Screenshots of IO scans are not a substitute, as they don‚Äôt show biological conditions, soft tissue, or occlusion checks.
üëâ Helle-note: Always take intraoral photos‚Äîit only takes a few minutes, and it gives you and your patient a reliable reference throughout treatment. Technicians can also deliver a far better setup when they have photos alongside the scan.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q216
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can I use existing x-rays?
synonyms: Do I need new x-rays for aligners?
How old can x-rays be for orthodontic planning?
Is it acceptable to reuse a patient‚Äôs previous panoramic or ceph?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes, existing x-rays can be used if they are recent and diagnostically valid. The key is ensuring that they still reflect the patient‚Äôs current condition.
Time frame ‚Äì Radiographs should generally be less than 12 months old for orthodontic use.
Diagnostic validity ‚Äì Make sure the image quality is sufficient and that the x-ray shows all relevant structures (roots, bone levels, pathology).
Changes in status ‚Äì If the patient has had extractions, trauma, or periodontal changes since the last x-ray, a new image may be required.
Medico-legal safety ‚Äì Using outdated or incomplete records can put you at risk if complications arise. When in doubt, take new baseline images.
üëâ Helle-note: It‚Äôs fine to reuse recent x-rays if they‚Äôre clear and relevant. Just make sure they truly reflect the patient‚Äôs current situation‚Äîotherwise, you risk missing something important at the very start of treatment.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q217
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Do I need to mark implants in the scan?
synonyms: How do I show implants in aligner cases?
Do I need to tell the technician about implants?
What happens if implants are not marked?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes. Implants must always be marked in the scan or prescription to prevent technicians from mistakenly planning movements on them.

question: When are OPG/CBCT images helpful?
synonyms: Do I need an OPG or CBCT before aligner treatment?
When should I order a panoramic x-ray or CBCT?
Which cases require 3D imaging?
answer_markdown:
A. Both OPG and CBCT can provide important diagnostic information, but their indications are different.
OPG (panoramic x-ray) ‚Äì Useful as an overall screening tool. It provides a broad overview of root morphology, bone levels, impacted or missing teeth, and general dental health. For most routine aligner cases, an OPG is sufficient.
CBCT (cone beam CT) ‚Äì Reserved for specific indications such as impacted or ectopic teeth, root-position‚Äìsensitive cases, suspected pathology, or pre-surgical planning. It should not be used routinely due to radiation dose and the risk of misinterpretation.
Limitations ‚Äì Aligner software that integrates CBCT for ‚Äútooth-in-bone‚Äù visualisation is only a graphic simulation, not a biological prediction of bone remodeling. This feature is ‚Äúnice-to-have‚Äù but should never be used as the basis for treatment planning or clinical decisions.
Best practice ‚Äì Apply the ALARA principle. Only order radiographs that are necessary for safe diagnosis and effective treatment planning.
üëâ Helle-note: An OPG is your standard overview tool and usually gives you what you need. A CBCT can be invaluable in special cases, but don‚Äôt let fancy software mislead you‚Äîbiological limits can‚Äôt be simulated. Keep it simple, safe, and evidence-based.

question: How much intrusion can I expect?
synonyms: Can aligners intrude teeth effectively?

answer_markdown:
A. Intrusion with aligners is possible, but limited. Predictability decreases as the amount of planned intrusion increases.
Predictable range ‚Äì Intrusion of 1‚Äì2 mm, especially of anterior teeth, is generally achievable with aligners alone. Special attention should be paid to anchorage. Remember Newtons 3rd law whenever you plan intrusion (and any other Orthodontic movement)
Beyond 2 mm ‚Äì Larger amounts of intrusion are unreliable without auxiliaries (e.g. TADs, elastics, bite ramps) or staged mechanics.
Posterior intrusion ‚Äì Much less predictable than anterior intrusion. Skeletal anchorage is usually required if more than minimal posterior intrusion is needed.
Monitoring ‚Äì Intrusion movements should be staged slowly and checked frequently for tracking loss or unwanted side effects (e.g. flaring of incisors).
üëâ Helle-note: Aligners can intrude, but only modestly. Plan conservatively‚Äîif you need more than 2 mm, add auxiliaries or consider a hybrid approach. That way you avoid frustration and give your patient a more stable result.

question: Is the overjet correction too ambitious?
synonyms: Can aligners correct large overjet?
How much overjet reduction is realistic with aligners?
Do I need anchorage for overjet correction?
answer_markdown:
A. Overjet reduction with aligners can be effective and predictable, but it is easy to over-plan. Excessive retraction without proper anchorage and staging risks loss of control and unstable results.
Anchorage requirements ‚Äì Significant overjet reduction demands strong anchorage. Without it, posterior teeth tend to drift mesially instead of incisors retracting.
Staging ‚Äì Retraction should be gradual and combined with space creation (IPR, distalisation, or extractions) to avoid excessive tipping of incisors. Retract first then recline the anteriors.
Elastics ‚Äì Class II elastics are often required, but their effectiveness is entirely dependent on patient compliance. The choice of buttons, cutouts, or hooks‚Äîand their exact position‚Äîshould always be guided by the side effects you want to control.
Button on upper canine: Reduces unwanted pull on the upper anterior segment, lowering the risk of retroclination and extrusion of the incisors. However, it increases the risk of distal tipping of the canine.
Button on lower molar: Our preferred option, as it reduces the risk of aligner displacement in the mandible. Placement must be considered carefully: if the molar needs mesial rotation, the button should be placed distally on the facial surface.
This logic applies to all tooth movements, but when elastics are introduced, complexity increases significantly. The digitally planned movements become less predictable because force vectors change depending on the elastics‚Äô length, thickness, strength, and‚Äîmost critically‚Äîhow many hours per day they are actually worn.
Skeletal anchorage ‚Äì Large corrections (>5‚Äì6 mm) often require TADs or a hybrid approach to ensure controlled movement and root positioning.
üëâ Helle-note: Be cautious with ambitious overjet corrections. Always double-check whether you have enough anchorage and compliance. If it looks too good to be true on the screen, it probably is‚Äîplan conservatively and protect your patient.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q326

question: How do I ensure correct posterior occlusion and avoid posterior open bite (POB)?

answer_markdown:
A. Posterior open bite (POB) is a common complication in aligner therapy. It often arises from inaccurate occlusal planning, over-extrusion of anteriors, interference from the aligner plastic‚Äîor insufficiently performed IPR compared to the treatment plan.
Settling stages ‚Äì Incorporate settling aligners or elastics at the end of treatment to allow posterior contacts to establish naturally.
Movement sequencing ‚Äì Avoid simultaneous extrusion and intrusion in multiple segments. Stage movements conservatively to maintain occlusal stability.
Occlusal balance ‚Äì Ensure planned end contacts are evenly distributed. Uneven occlusal stops increase the risk of POB.
IPR accuracy ‚Äì Clinical studies show that IPR is often performed less precisely than planned, which can directly lead to posterior open bites. Using a calibrated IPR system‚Äîsuch as the one from Dentatus we recommend‚Äîsignificantly increases precision and reduces the risk of POB.
Monitoring ‚Äì Check early for premature anterior contacts that may prevent posterior settling. Adjust in refinements if necessary.
üëâ Helle-note: Posterior open bites are frustrating but preventable. Plan carefully, move conservatively, perform IPR with precision, and always allow time for the bite to settle. question: What happens if aligners are lost during treatment?

answer_markdown:
A. Lost aligners are a common occurrence and management depends on the treatment stage and how well the teeth have tracked.
Early stages ‚Äì If an aligner is lost within the first few days of wear, teeth have not adapted yet. In most cases, you should reorder the aligner or step back to the previous one to avoid loss of tracking.
Later stages ‚Äì If the aligner was worn for most of its scheduled time (e.g. 10‚Äì12 days of a 14-day cycle), it is often safe to advance to the next aligner, provided fit is verified.
Fit check ‚Äì Always assess the fit of the next aligner. If it doesn‚Äôt seat properly, don‚Äôt force it‚Äîorder a replacement or return to the last aligner that fit well.
Prevention ‚Äì Advise patients to store aligners in a case when not in use and keep the previous set until the new one fits well.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt panic if an aligner is lost‚Äîit happens all the time. The key is to check the stage and fit before deciding whether to move forward or reorder. Remind patients to always keep their previous set as a backup. This simple habit prevents delays and frustration.

question: Can aligners move roots, not just crowns?

answer_markdown:
A. Yes, aligners can move roots‚Äînot just crowns‚Äîbut this requires precise planning and mechanics. Root control is one of the most technique-sensitive aspects of aligner therapy.
Torque control ‚Äì Controlled root movement depends on proper torque planning. Aligners alone tend to tip teeth unless auxiliaries and optimized mechanics are used.
Attachments ‚Äì Optimized root control or torque attachments increase surface area for force application and help direct forces apically.

question: What‚Äôs the maximum rotation correction for laterals?

A. Lateral incisor rotations can be corrected with aligners, but predictability decreases as the degree of rotation increases.

question: Is torque control realistic, and what helps?

answer_markdown:
A. Torque control is one of the more challenging aspects of aligner biomechanics, but with the right tools and staging it is achievable.
Predictability ‚Äì Moderate torque movements are possible, but predictability is lower than with fixed appliances. Aligners alone tend to produce tipping if not reinforced.
Attachments ‚Äì Optimized or rectangular torque attachments increase surface area and improve force delivery for root control.
Trimline design ‚Äì Systems with a straight trimline generally provide better torque expression due to improved aligner rigidity and retention.
Auxiliaries ‚Äì TADs, sectional wires, or elastics may be required in cases needing significant root control. These ensure forces are directed more apically rather than just crown-focused.
Staging ‚Äì Torque must be planned slowly in small increments, with careful monitoring for tracking loss.
üëâ Helle-note: Torque control is possible, but don‚Äôt expect miracles. Use the right attachments, plan conservatively, and remember that straight trimline systems usually give you better biomechanics. If you want us to, we can help design setups that achieve torque movements more predictably‚Äîsaving you time in refinements.

question: How do I prevent black triangles?
synonyms: Can aligners cause black triangles?
How do I close spaces between teeth?
What prevents gaps at the gingival margin?
answer_markdown:
A. Black triangles are usually caused by root angulation and loss of papilla support. Prevention requires careful biomechanical planning and precise execution.
IPR staging ‚Äì Plan and perform interproximal reduction gradually in the right locations. This reshapes contact points and allows teeth to move into tighter contact.
Root control ‚Äì Aligners tend to tip crowns together, leaving roots divergent. Use proper torque and root angulation to ensure parallel roots and stable papilla support.
Axial inclinations ‚Äì Focus on correct axial inclinations rather than ‚Äúovercorrection.‚Äù Properly aligned roots eliminate the need for artificial compensations.
Monitoring ‚Äì Regularly assess contacts and papilla fill throughout treatment. Address tracking or angulation problems early to avoid permanent gaps.
üëâ Helle-note: Black triangles are among the most common esthetic complaints after aligner treatment. The solution is not fancy tricks but a) patient information prior to treatment b) solid biomechanics: parallel roots, precise IPR, and controlled staging. Sometimes black triangles can‚Äôt be eliminated completely but only reduced. If you‚Äôd like, we can help design your setups to minimise the risk and save you refinements later.

question: Can aligners achieve segmental movements?

How predictable are localised tooth movements?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes, aligners can achieve segmental movements, but predictability depends on anchorage, attachments, and staging. Moving a small section of teeth is often more reliable than attempting the same movement across the entire arch.
Attachments and auxiliaries ‚Äì Buttons, optimized attachments, and elastics improve control of localised movements.
Staging ‚Äì Local or sequential staging (e.g. distalising a quadrant or intruding a group of teeth) is more predictable than full-arch simultaneous movements.
Anchorage ‚Äì Segmental movements require anchorage planning to prevent unwanted reciprocal effects elsewhere in the arch.
Indications ‚Äì Useful for midline correction, unilateral distalisation, or targeted intrusion/extrusion.
üëâ Helle-note: Aligners are not just for ‚Äúfull arch‚Äù movements. Segmental approaches can be very effective‚Äîif you plan them carefully and use the right auxiliaries. Want help designing a setup that moves only what you want, while keeping the rest stable? That‚Äôs exactly the kind of planning support we provide.

question: How do I ensure correct midline correction?

Do I need elastics for midline cases?
answer_markdown:
A. Midline correction with aligners is possible, but it requires anchorage planning and careful control of tooth movement. Without balance, space closure alone can create asymmetric results or loss of root control.
Anchorage ‚Äì Strong anchorage is essential. Without it, attempts at midline correction often result in reciprocal unwanted movements.
Torque control ‚Äì Maintain proper root angulation during space closure to avoid black triangles or unstable contacts.
Movement planning ‚Äì Plan whether correction will come from unilateral distalisation, asymmetric IPR, extractions, or space redistribution.
Elastics ‚Äì For larger midline shifts, cross-arch elastics are often necessary to achieve controlled and stable correction.
üëâ Helle-note: Midline correction looks straightforward on-screen, but in reality it‚Äôs one of the trickiest movements to get right. Balance anchorage, torque, and space closure carefully. question: How much expansion is predictable vs. planned?
synonyms: Can aligners really expand the arch?
Is aligner expansion stable?
What kind of expansion can I expect with clear aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Expansion with aligners is possible, but most of the change comes from crown tipping rather than true bodily movement. Predictability decreases as the planned amount increases.
Crown tipping vs. bodily movement ‚Äì Aligners commonly produce buccal tipping of crowns. True bodily expansion (moving roots laterally) is far less predictable. However not impossible if planned correctly in combination with a suitable aligner system.
Amount of expansion ‚Äì Mild to moderate expansion is achievable, but large amounts often require auxiliaries or restorative adjustments.
Stability ‚Äì Tipped teeth are prone to relapse if not supported. Long-term stability depends on the retention strategy.
IPR balance ‚Äì Combine expansion with IPR where appropriate to reduce excessive flaring and maintain root alignment.
üëâ Helle-note: Expansion looks impressive on the screen, but don‚Äôt overpromise. Most of what you get is crown tipping, not real bodily movement unless you slow down movements considerably and accept the need for revisions. Plan conservatively, add IPR when needed, and if you want a predictable expansion strategy, we can help design one that saves you refinements.

question: Can I combine aligners with mini-screws/TADs?
synonyms: Can TADs be used with aligners?

When should I consider TADs in aligner therapy?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes. Temporary Anchorage Devices (TADs) can be combined with aligners to provide absolute anchorage for movements that are otherwise difficult or unpredictable.
Distalisation ‚Äì TADs can stabilise posterior segments, making distalisation of molars or entire quadrants more predictable.
Intrusion ‚Äì Skeletal anchorage is often essential for reliable posterior or anterior intrusion beyond 1‚Äì2 mm.
Torque control ‚Äì TADs can provide additional anchorage points for elastics or auxiliaries when significant root torque is required.
Complex cases ‚Äì In open bite, deep bite, or severe asymmetry cases, TADs allow biomechanical control that aligners alone cannot provide.
Critical decision point ‚Äì Even though you can achieve a lot with TADs and power arms, there comes a point where you must ask: Is an aligner system really the best tool for this case, or should I consider a different type of appliance?
üëâ Helle-note: TADs are one of the best ways to expand what‚Äôs possible with aligners. But remember‚Äînot every case is an ‚Äúaligner case.‚Äù Use TADs where they make sense, but don‚Äôt be afraid to choose another system if biomechanics demand it. If you‚Äôd like, we can help evaluate whether aligners (with or without TADs) are the right choice for your patient.

question: How do I deal with a patient who stops wearing aligners?
synonyms: What if my patient isn‚Äôt compliant with aligners?
How do I manage poor aligner wear?
What if the patient takes long breaks in treatment?
answer_markdown:
A. Poor compliance is one of the main causes of aligner treatment failure. When a patient stops wearing aligners, the first step is to assess the situation and reset expectations.
Assess the stage ‚Äì Check how many days the last aligner was worn and whether teeth have relapsed. If fit is poor, you may need to backtrack to the previous aligner or order replacements.
Reset expectations ‚Äì Explain clearly that aligners only work when worn 20‚Äì22 hours per day. Use photos, scans, or tracking aids to show the patient what‚Äôs been lost.
Motivation strategy ‚Äì Explore the reasons behind poor compliance (comfort, esthetics, lifestyle). Sometimes simple adjustments‚Äîlike trimming edges or changing routines‚Äîcan improve adherence.
Plan modification ‚Äì In severe cases, you may need to redesign the treatment, extend wear time, or even consider switching to fixed appliances.
üëâ Helle-note: Non-compliance happens, and it‚Äôs usually not malice‚Äîit‚Äôs life getting in the way. Be firm but supportive when you reset expectations. And remember, we can help redesign stalled treatments into realistic plans that get your patient back on track‚Äîsaving you time and frustration.

question: Are cross elastics effective with aligners?
synonyms: Can cross elastics correct crossbites with aligners?
Do I need buttons for cross elastics?
How well do elastics work with aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes, cross elastics can be effective with aligners, especially for correcting dental crossbites. Success depends on compliance, attachment design, and careful staging.
When to use ‚Äì Cross elastics are helpful in unilateral or dental crossbite cases where tipping movements are needed.
Attachments/buttons ‚Äì Elastics require bonded buttons or precision cuts in the aligners for reliable anchorage.
Patient compliance ‚Äì Results depend heavily on patients wearing elastics as prescribed. Without consistent wear, correction will stall.
Limits ‚Äì Skeletal crossbites are not correctable with elastics alone; they require expansion appliances or surgery.
üëâ Helle-note: Cross elastics can make a big difference in dental crossbite cases‚Äîbut only if patients actually wear them. Set clear expectations and keep it simple. And if you‚Äôre not sure how to integrate elastics into your setup, we can help plan it predictably.

question: When should I use attachments vs bite ramps/disclusion features?
synonyms: What‚Äôs the difference between attachments and bite ramps?
When do I use disclusion features instead of attachments?
Do bite ramps replace attachments?
answer_markdown:
A. Attachments and bite ramps/disclusion features serve different purposes, and they are often complementary rather than interchangeable. Choosing the right tool depends on whether you are aiming to control tooth movement or manage the bite.
Attachments ‚Äì Provide grip and force application for controlled movements such as extrusion, rotations, torque, and root control. They increase the aligner‚Äôs ability to transmit forces to specific teeth.
Bite ramps/disclusion features ‚Äì Used mainly for bite correction and disocclusion. They help disengage posterior teeth, facilitate movements like deep bite correction, and support vertical control. Contrary to a common misconception, bite ramps do not intrude anterior teeth. They don‚Äôt increase pressure on incisors‚Äîin fact, they trigger a neuro-feedback loop that reduces muscle activity by ~90%. This can lead to the condyles seating in CR and, because posterior teeth are separated, may allow (limited) posterior extrusion.
System differences ‚Äì Not all bite ramps are created equal. Some aligner systems (e.g. SureSmile) use ramps so small they are ineffective. For bite ramps to work, they must be large enough for the patient to bite only on them‚Äîand nothing else.
Combined use ‚Äì Many cases benefit from both: attachments to control tooth biomechanics and bite ramps to manage occlusion and functional changes.
üëâ Helle-note: Think of attachments as your ‚Äúhandles‚Äù to move teeth and bite ramps as your ‚Äúbite managers.‚Äù Just don‚Äôt expect ramps to intrude incisors‚Äîthey don‚Äôt. If you‚Äôre unsure whether the ramps in your chosen system are actually effective, let us help you evaluate the setup before you approve it.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q540

question: When should I prefer horizontal vs vertical attachments?
synonyms: What‚Äôs the difference between horizontal and vertical attachments?
When should I use horizontal attachments instead of vertical ones?
Do vertical attachments control movements better?
answer_markdown:
A. Horizontal and vertical attachments transmit forces differently. The choice depends on which movement you want to control and which aligner system you‚Äôre working with.
Vertical attachments ‚Äì More surface area for grip on round teeth (especially premolars). They are particularly useful for rotations and general retention.
Horizontal attachments ‚Äì Better suited for extrusion and certain vertical control tasks, since the aligner engages more effectively in the incisal‚Äìgingival direction.
Torque control ‚Äì Critical mainly in systems with a scalloped trimline, since these systems struggle to transfer enough force from the aligner to the root. In these systems the attachment adds retention surface which helps transfer more force. In straight trimline systems, torque is more predictable and often doesn‚Äôt require as aggressive attachment strategies.
System-specific design ‚Äì Some software suggests ‚Äúoptimized attachments,‚Äù but you should always evaluate whether they make biomechanical sense in your case.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt just accept whatever attachment the software throws at you. Vertical attachments are generally your go-to for rotations and grip, horizontals for extrusion‚Äîbut remember, torque control is a much bigger issue in scalloped systems. If you‚Äôre unsure, we can help adjust the plan so the attachments actually work in real life, not just on the screen.

question: Do I always need optimized attachments, or can conventional ones work?
synonyms: Are optimized attachments better than conventional ones?
Can I still use traditional attachments?
When should I override optimized designs?
answer_markdown:
A. Optimized attachments are designed by software algorithms to improve biomechanics for specific movements, but they are not always necessary‚Äîor superior. Conventional attachments can often work just as well when applied thoughtfully.
Optimized attachments ‚Äì Generated automatically to match specific planned movements (e.g. rotations, torque, extrusion). They can be helpful, but are sometimes impractical or placed in non-ideal positions.
Conventional attachments ‚Äì Rectangular, ellipsoid, or beveled attachments placed manually by the clinician. They can provide excellent control when positioned and sized correctly. No study on attachments and attachment designs have been able to prove any difference between the efficiency or effectiveness of classic rectangular attachments or optimised attachments.
Clinical judgment ‚Äì Rely on your own biomechanical knowledge. If an optimized attachment looks illogical, don‚Äôt hesitate to replace it with a conventional design that better suits your treatment goals.
System variation ‚Äì Some systems over-rely on optimized attachments, especially those with scalloped trimlines. In straight trimline systems with stronger aligner grip, conventional attachments are often sufficient.
üëâ Helle-note: Optimized rarely means ‚Äúbetter.‚Äù Trust your own clinical eye‚Äîif the software places an attachment that makes no sense, replace it. Attachments are just tools, and sometimes the simplest conventional option works best. If you‚Äôd like, we can help you decide when to keep or override the optimized ones.

question: How many attachments are really necessary?

Strategic placement ‚Äì Place attachments only where they add biomechanical value (e.g. rotations, torque, extrusion). Avoid ‚Äúdecoration‚Äù attachments that don‚Äôt serve a purpose.
Patient comfort ‚Äì Fewer attachments reduce bulk, improve patient comfort, and make hygiene easier.
Aligner fit ‚Äì Well-fitting aligners with proper trimline design can reduce the need for excessive attachments.
Clinical efficiency ‚Äì Each attachment placement and removal costs chair time. Fewer, smarter attachments save both you and the patient time.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt let the software plaster attachments everywhere. Less is often more. Think quality over quantity‚Äîstrategic placement beats numbers every time. If you want, we can help streamline setups so you only place the attachments that truly matter.

question: Can I avoid visible attachments on anterior teeth?

A. In many cases, yes‚Äîyou can reduce or avoid visible attachments on anterior teeth. However, this often comes at the cost of less control over torque and rotations.

question: How long should attachments stay on?

question: Are optimized/engineered attachments always better than standard shapes?
synonyms: Should I always trust optimized attachments?

answer_markdown:
A. No‚Äîthere is no scientific evidence that optimized/engineered attachments outperform standard shapes. While the academic ideas and engineering principles behind them are clever, they don‚Äôt necessarily translate into better results in real patients.
Theory vs practice ‚Äì Optimized and beveled attachments are built on sound biomechanical theories. But in reality, aligners wear down, don‚Äôt always fit perfectly, and plastic properties limit force transfer.
Clinical reality ‚Äì In practice, theory often gets overtaken by the realities of the mouth. Conventional attachments‚Äîthough slightly bigger and less ‚Äúfancy‚Äù‚Äîconsistently deliver more reliable control.
Evidence base ‚Äì No peer-reviewed study has demonstrated that optimized designs perform better than conventional ones in predictable clinical outcomes.
Our preference ‚Äì We prefer conventional attachments because they work every time, even when conditions aren‚Äôt perfect. Simplicity and predictability outweigh theoretical elegance.

question: Which bonding material works best for attachments?

There are exceptions as some materials bond to the aligner material which leads to attachments breaking of when the template os removed. question: How much enamel can be safely removed?

Is there a maximum for interproximal reduction?
answer_markdown:
A. Interproximal reduction (IPR) is safe when performed within biological limits. The key is to stay conservative, measure precisely, and distribute space creation evenly.
Per contact ‚Äì Up to 0.3 mm per contact is considered safe without compromising enamel integrity.
Cumulative limit ‚Äì Never remove more than 50% of total interproximal enamel on a given tooth over the course of treatment.
Clinical judgment ‚Äì Always balance esthetics, space needs, and periodontal health. Over-reduction risks sensitivity, caries, or long-term instability.
Precision tools ‚Äì We always recommend the Dentatus IPR system. It is the only calibrated system in the world and provides the most accurate results. Because it is machine-driven (requires a reciprocating handpiece such as Profin or Eva), it is also many times faster than any manual method.
üëâ Helle-note: IPR is a fantastic tool‚Äîbut only if used precisely. Stay conservative, measure carefully, and spread reduction across multiple contacts rather than overdoing it on one tooth. The Dentatus system makes IPR both faster and more predictable, which is why we recommend it for every case.

question: Should I perform IPR all at once or gradually?
synonyms: Is it better to do IPR in one visit?
Can I split IPR over several appointments?
What‚Äôs the safest way to time IPR?
answer_markdown:
A. Whether IPR should be performed all at once or gradually depends on the clinical situation. If access and bone support allow, completing IPR in one session is preferable. In more complex cases, staged reduction may be the only safe option.
All at once ‚Äì When rotations and crowding permit, it is best to complete IPR in a single session. This ensures accuracy, reduces cumulative chair time, and allows teeth to move predictably according to the treatment plan.
Sequential IPR ‚Äì In cases with severely rotated teeth or limited bone support, IPR may need to be performed gradually as teeth are aligned. This avoids damaging enamel or overstepping biological limits.
Avoid round tripping ‚Äì A common method has been to procline teeth first to gain access for IPR, and then retract them. However, this often leads to loss of facial bone‚Äîwhich does not regenerate. Therefore, we strongly recommend avoiding round tripping.
Case-specific planning ‚Äì Always check whether the planned tooth positions make IPR feasible without compromising enamel or bone. Adjust sequencing if needed.
üëâ Helle-note: Do IPR in one go if you can‚Äîit‚Äôs more efficient and predictable. But if rotations or bone levels limit access, take it in stages. Just never rely on round tripping‚Äîit costs bone, and bone won‚Äôt come back. We can help you evaluate your case so you know whether to do IPR all at once or in sequences.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q652

question: Which instruments are recommended?
synonyms: What‚Äôs the best tool for IPR?

Which IPR system is most accurate?

question: How do I correct an IPR mistake?

answer_markdown:
A. Mistakes in IPR happen, but they can usually be corrected if addressed thoughtfully. The approach depends on whether too much or too little enamel was removed‚Äîand when the mistake is discovered.
Too little reduction ‚Äì If discovered immediately, complete the missing IPR using a calibrated system. Alternative strategy ‚Äì IPR can sometimes be done between teeth with large approximal fillings or crowns, provided you are willing to redo them. Even here, biological limits apply: maintain safe interdental distances and avoid over-reduction.
Too much reduction ‚Äì If excessive enamel was removed, restorative reshaping (e.g. composite build-ups) may be necessary to restore contacts, esthetics, and stability.

üëâ Helle-note: The worst IPR mistakes usually come from under-reduction that goes unnoticed until it‚Äôs too late. Once the patient has worn aligners, you‚Äôve lost calibration forever. question: How do I correct an IPR mistake?

Alternative sites ‚Äì If additional reduction is needed, consider performing IPR between teeth with existing approximal fillings or crowns (if you are ready to redo them), but always respect biological limits.

question: When are elastics necessary, and how do I avoid unwanted side effects?

answer_markdown:
A. Elastics are a valuable tool in aligner therapy, but they must be used with caution. They are primarily indicated for sagittal corrections (Class II or III), anchorage, or midline adjustments, but they can also be used creatively as ‚Äúhacks‚Äù to correct movements that don‚Äôt track as planned.

Class II & III planning ‚Äì Requires careful strategy, not just in force application but also in the choice of buttons vs hooks/slits in the aligners. Each has pros and cons and will affect how Newton‚Äôs 3rd law plays out (equal and opposite forces ‚Üí unwanted tipping/rotation if not anticipated).
Side effects ‚Äì Elastics can extrude teeth and open the bite or tip molars. Plan anchorage, staging, and attachment design to counteract these.
Advanced anchorage ‚Äì Power arms and TADs nearly always require elastics to deliver controlled forces. These setups are more complex and need careful biomechanical planning.
üëâ Helle-note: Elastics are powerful allies, but they‚Äôre also tricky. Used well, they can save a case; used poorly, they can ruin it. Buttons, hooks, cutouts‚Äîevery choice matters, and every force has an equal opposite reaction. If you‚Äôd like, we can help you plan elastic use so you get the benefits without the headaches.

question: How are elastics integrated into aligner treatment?

answer_markdown:
A. Elastics can be integrated into aligner treatment using either buttons bonded to teeth or precision cuts/hooks built into the aligners. Each approach has its pros and cons, and the choice depends on your treatment goals and the side effects you want to minimise.
Buttons on teeth ‚Äì Provide strong anchorage but create esthetic concerns and require careful placement. The exact position of a button determines how forces are expressed‚Äîpoor placement can cause unwanted tipping or rotations.
Precision cuts/hooks ‚Äì More esthetic and convenient since they are built into the aligner, but the plastic can deform under stress, reducing force effectiveness. Always ensure large, solid attachments on both sides of the slit/hook‚Äîotherwise, the aligner risks being pulled off the teeth, either partially or completely.
Biomechanical planning ‚Äì Whether using buttons or hooks, consider Newton‚Äôs 3rd law: every elastic force produces an equal and opposite reaction. Placement determines whether you amplify or counteract side effects such as bite opening, molar tipping, or incisor flaring.
Combination strategies ‚Äì In complex cases, a mix of bonded buttons and aligner cutouts may be needed for optimal force distribution.
üëâ Helle-note: Elastics are simple in theory but tricky in practice. Whether you use buttons or precision cuts, placement is everything. And don‚Äôt forget‚Äîwithout strong attachments to anchor them, precision cuts can pull aligners off mid-treatment. question: How do I manage clicking sounds, discomfort, or posterior open bite?

answer_markdown:
A. Clicking sounds, discomfort, and posterior open bites can occur during aligner treatment, but they should never be ignored. New TMJ sounds developing after treatment has started are red flags and should prompt reevaluation.
Clicking sounds (TMJ) ‚Äì If new joint sounds appear during aligner therapy, this is abnormal. Clicking often indicates disc displacement. Aligners can aggravate pre-existing TMJ conditions if they were not diagnosed before treatment. That‚Äôs why a complete orthodontic diagnostic work-up must always include TMJ assessment before treatment begins.
Biteramps for support ‚Äì In cases where TMJ stability is a concern, biteramps may help ensure that the condyles seat properly during treatment (provided the patient can occlude on them). Class II patients can be more challenging here, as overjet may prevent effective ramp contact.
Discomfort ‚Äì Mild soreness with each new aligner is normal. Prolonged or localized pain, however, may indicate excessive force, poor tracking, or occlusal interferences.
Posterior open bite (POB) ‚Äì Common in aligner therapy. Often linked to insufficient IPR, incomplete aligner seating, or bite changes due to staging. POBs are also frequently observed in patients with strong clenching habits‚Äîespecially those with a reduced mandibular angle and hyperactive masseter muscles.
Troubleshooting ‚Äì Minor POB can sometimes settle naturally post-treatment, but persistent cases require refinements or finishing mechanics (e.g., elastics or selective equilibration). Always re-check occlusion, staging, IPR accuracy, and ensure TMJ stability.
üëâ Helle-note: New TMJ noises are never ‚Äújust part of treatment.‚Äù They‚Äôre warning signs. And remember‚Äîposterior open bites often happen in heavy clenchers with strong muscles. Don‚Äôt dismiss them. We‚Äôll help you decide when to wait, when to refine, and when to intervene with supportive mechanics like elastics or ramps.

question: What signs show poor compliance?
synonyms: How do I know if my patient isn‚Äôt wearing aligners enough?
What are the warning signs of non-compliance?
How can I tell if aligners aren‚Äôt being worn properly?
answer_markdown:
A. Poor compliance is the single most common reason for treatment failure in aligner therapy. Recognising the signs early helps you intervene before the case derails.
Tracking problems ‚Äì Aligners no longer seat fully on teeth, especially on incisors or rotated teeth. Gaps between plastic and tooth surface are a classic giveaway.
Delayed movements ‚Äì Teeth lag behind the digital plan. Movements such as rotations, torque, or space closure are slower or incomplete.
Wear patterns ‚Äì Aligners look pristine after a week, showing little or no signs of use. With good compliance, aligners usually show slight wear or cloudiness.
Patient feedback ‚Äì Patients often admit indirectly: ‚ÄúI only wore them at night‚Äù or ‚ÄúI forgot a few days.‚Äù
Frequent refinements ‚Äì Repeated need for new scans and refinements without clinical justification often indicates compliance issues rather than treatment failure.
üëâ Helle-note: Compliance problems are easy to spot once you know what to look for. The real challenge is addressing them without making the patient defensive. We can help you with communication strategies that turn non-compliant patients into motivated partners in their own treatment.

question: Can aligners be combined with implants?
synonyms: Can I do aligner treatment if the patient has implants?
Do implants move with aligners?
How do I plan aligners around existing implants?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes‚Äîaligners can be combined with implants, but planning must account for the fact that implants are ankylosed and cannot move. This makes them both a limitation and an opportunity.
Implants don‚Äôt move ‚Äì Unlike natural teeth, implants are fixed in the bone. They cannot be moved orthodontically.
Use as anchorage ‚Äì Implants can serve as stable anchorage units, supporting controlled movement of adjacent teeth.
Staging considerations ‚Äì Tooth movements should be planned around implants. Avoid attempting space closure across an implant site.
Future implants ‚Äì If implants are to be placed after orthodontic treatment, aligners can be used to create ideal space and root angulation beforehand.
Occlusal planning ‚Äì Pay attention to final occlusion: implants should be placed/restored only after teeth are in their final planned position.
üëâ Helle-note: Implants and aligners can work beautifully together‚Äîbut only if you respect the biology. Use implants for anchorage, don‚Äôt try to move them, and always plan restorative timing carefully. We can help you sequence ortho-restorative cases so the end result is both functional and esthetic.

question: How do I plan ortho-restorative cases with veneers/crowns?Also asked as: "What is ortho-restorative treatment?", "How do I combine aligners with restorative dentistry?", "When should veneers or crowns be placed in relation to orthodontics?"
answer_markdown:
A. Ortho-restorative cases are defined as situations where teeth are moved into an ideal position with aligners beforeveneers, crowns, or other restorative treatment is carried out. This sequencing makes restorative work more conservative, more esthetic, and longer lasting.
Definition ‚Äì Ortho-restorative cases mean orthodontics first, restoration second. It‚Äôs not about bonding to porcelain or moving existing crowns, but about creating the correct foundation before final restorations.
Why sequence matters ‚Äì Restorations placed before orthodontics often need to be replaced afterwards. By aligning teeth first, you minimise the need for unnecessary rework.
Digital smile design ‚Äì To achieve ideal results, it is recommended to create a digital smile design, ideally combined with a digital mock-up that shows the desired end result. This enables precise planning of tooth positions, reducing the need for aggressive tooth preparation.
Ideal positioning ‚Äì Aligners are used to optimise tooth angulation, spacing, and occlusion before restorative design, allowing thinner, more conservative, and more natural-looking restorations.
Teamwork ‚Äì Close collaboration between the orthodontist/aligner specialist and the restorative dentist ensures that space, shape, and smile design all align with the patient‚Äôs esthetic and functional goals. This is where digital dentistry excels, as it enables collaboration with experts from anywhere in the world. We are, of course, happy to assist in developing an ortho-restorative treatment plan. If needed, we can also help the dentist choose and implement the most suitable digital platform for creating a smile design.
Retention ‚Äì A critical aspect of ortho-restorative treatment is ensuring ideal retention throughout the post-orthodontic restorative phase. This is often more challenging than it appears, and without proper retention, even the best restorative plan risks instability. Several approaches to predictable retention during the restorative phase are described in detail in our book ‚ÄúMastering Aligner Orthodontics‚Äù. https://www.alignerservice.com/product-page/mastering-aligner-orthodontics
üëâ Helle-note: Think of aligners as setting the stage and restorations as the performance. With digital smile design, you can show patients the ‚Äúafter‚Äù before you even begin‚Äîand plan tooth movements so minimally invasive dentistry becomes the standard.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q1092

question: Can aligners create space for a bridge or implant?
synonyms: Can aligners open space for missing teeth?
Can I use aligners to prepare for implant placement?
Do aligners help in bridge planning?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes‚Äîaligners can be highly effective for creating restorative space when teeth are missing, but careful planning is essential. They can upright adjacent teeth, redistribute space, and optimise root angulation to prepare for implant or bridge placement.
Space creation ‚Äì Aligners can open or redistribute space mesio-distally, creating the correct gap for an implant or pontic.
Uprighting adjacent teeth ‚Äì Tilted teeth next to edentulous spaces can be uprighted, improving prosthetic space and simplifying restorative work.
Root parallelism ‚Äì Aligners can move roots into more ideal positions, ensuring enough space for implants without root collisions. However, root movements are generally more challenging with aligners than with fixed braces. Auxiliaries like power arms and TADs may be necessary depending on the initial situation.
Timing of implant placement ‚Äì Implant insertion should always be delayed until orthodontic movements are completed. Teeth must be stable and positioned correctly before prosthetic work begins.
Restorative integration ‚Äì Use digital smile design and mock-ups to plan final tooth and implant positions. This reduces invasive prep and ensures alignment between ortho and restorative goals.
üëâ Helle-note: Aligners are not just for straightening teeth‚Äîthey can prepare the perfect foundation for implants and bridges. But remember: roots are harder to move with aligners. Sometimes auxiliaries are the key to unlocking predictable space creation. We can help you judge when aligners alone are enough‚Äîand when you should add extra tools.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q1093

question: How should I handle patients with periodontitis?
synonyms: Can patients with periodontal disease have aligners?
Is periodontitis a contraindication for orthodontics?
How do I plan aligner treatment with reduced bone support?
answer_markdown:
A. Periodontitis does not exclude patients from aligner treatment, but active disease is an absolute contraindication. Treatment should only begin once periodontal health is stabilised and maintained stable for at least 6 month.
Absolute contraindication ‚Äì Active periodontal disease is one of the fastest ways to destroy bone support if orthodontics is started. Never treat until inflammation is eliminated.
Stability first ‚Äì Ensure 3‚Äì6 months of stable periodontal health (no active pockets, mobility, or bleeding on probing at all!) before considering orthodontics.
Light, controlled forces ‚Äì Reduced bone support means teeth move more easily, but also less stably. Apply lighter forces, use slower staging, and avoid aggressive expansion.
Hygiene focus ‚Äì Patients must maintain excellent oral hygiene throughout treatment. Frequent recalls (every 3 months or as recommended by the periodontist) are essential. If there is any sign of active periodontal disease - stop the treatment and let the patient use the current aligner as retention until ideal periodontal health has been reestablished before continuing any orthodontic movements.
Collaboration ‚Äì Always plan and monitor these cases together with a periodontist. Interdisciplinary teamwork ensures both periodontal and orthodontic success.
üëâ Helle-note: Periodontal patients can be treated with aligners‚Äîbut only if the foundation is stable. Think of it like building on weak ground: unless you reinforce it first, the whole structure collapses. We‚Äôll help you adjust force levels and plan realistically so you protect, not endanger, your patient‚Äôs teeth.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH03:SEC15:spacing-and-crowding, MAO:TBD:q1094

question: Can aligners be combined with fixed appliances?
synonyms: Can I use braces and aligners together?
What is a hybrid orthodontic treatment?
When should I switch from aligners to braces?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes‚Äîaligners can be combined with fixed appliances in so-called hybrid treatments. This is often the best option when certain movements are too unpredictable or inefficient with aligners alone.
Indications ‚Äì Hybrid treatments are especially useful for difficult rotations, large root movements, severe torque control, or cases where anchorage demands exceed aligner capacity.
Sequencing ‚Äì Many clinicians begin with fixed appliances for complex movements (e.g., derotation of lower canines) and then switch to aligners for finishing and esthetics. Others use aligners first and finish with fixed brackets for detailing.
Attachments vs brackets ‚Äì In some cases, replacing an attachment with a bracket and sectional wire provides better control of a specific tooth without abandoning the aligner treatment altogether.
Patient communication ‚Äì Emphasise to patients that combining systems is not a failure, but a way to achieve a more predictable and efficient result.
üëâ Helle-note: Sometimes aligners can‚Äôt do it all, sometimes fixed appliances are not ideal for specific movements‚Äîand that‚Äôs okay. Using a few brackets or wires strategically can save you months of frustration. We‚Äôve seen hybrid treatments turn ‚Äúdifficult‚Äù cases into predictable successes.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH04:SEC07:tooth-movements-definitions, MAO:TBD:q1095
