question: Can aligners be used as retention?
synonyms: Can patients use aligners instead of retainers?
Are Vivera retainers necessary after Ortho?
Can finished ortho cases be maintained with aligners?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes‚Äîaligners or aligner-style retainers (e.g. Vivera-type retainers) can be used for long-term retention after braces or aligner therapy. They are esthetic and comfortable, but must be part of a structured retention protocol.
Our retention protocol ‚Äì
Last aligner: 3 months, 22 hours/day
Next 3 months: 16 hours/day
Thereafter (lifelong): 8 hours/day
Biological considerations ‚Äì Not all movements are equally stable. Canine rotations and significant rotations of other teeth are especially prone to relapse. In these cases, clear aligners alone are insufficient. A bonded retainer(e.g. lower 1st premolar to 1st premolar, upper canine to canine) should always be added, ideally combined with a removable retainer.
Settling effect ‚Äì When an aligner retainer is made from the last step of the aligner plan (not a new scan), teeth often settle into a slightly better occlusion, as they settle more into the digitally planned end position. This ‚Äúsettling‚Äù effect can improve precision.
Limitations of aligner retainers ‚Äì Aligner material does not allow natural occlusal settling. Long-term, patients also sleep with plastic between their teeth, and the effects on muscles and joints are not yet fully understood.
Alternative strategy ‚Äì With more experience, we increasingly recommend bonded retainers (mandible: 1st premolar to 1st premolar, maxilla: canine to canine) combined with a removable retainer (Jensen or Hawley plate in the upper arch). This balances stability, function, and patient comfort.
Quality of retainers ‚Äì In our experience, retainers produced by aligner companies are more precise and durable than Essix retainers made in-house or by orthodontic labs. Therefore, aligner-manufactured retainers are preferred when following this strategy.
üëâ Helle-note: Retention is not one-size-fits-all. Some cases can manage with aligner retainers, others demand bonded wires. The important part is thinking ahead‚Äîplan retention just as carefully as the treatment itself. We can help you tailor the right mix of bonded and removable solutions for each case.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q1096
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: How do aligners work with cosmetic veneers?
synonyms: Can patients with veneers have aligner treatment?
Will aligners damage veneers?
Are veneers an alternative to orthodontics?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners can be used in patients with veneers, but movements may be limited and the risk of debonding will always be present. Planning must be realistic, with a focus on function, stability, and long-term retention.
Limitations ‚Äì Veneers may be added to cover crowding. This results in big amounts of approximal porcelain which can limit the type of movements you can perform unless the veneers are being removed. Any orthodontic treatment entails a risk of debonding or fracturing restorations.
Retention challenges ‚Äì Veneers have historically been promoted as ‚Äúinstant orthodontics.‚Äù But without orthodontic correction and proper retention, teeth will reposition themselves according to functional balance (lips, cheeks, tongue). This often leads to anterior crowding‚Äîand a worse starting point for future restorative work.
Ideal sequencing ‚Äì The best approach is to first reposition teeth orthodontically with aligners, then perform veneer treatment afterwards. This minimises tooth preparation, improves long-term stability, and enhances esthetics.
Patient expectations ‚Äì Cosmetic patients often have high esthetic demands. Be transparent about what aligners can and cannot achieve on veneered teeth, and explain why retention is critical after combined ortho-restorative treatment.
Team approach ‚Äì Close collaboration between orthodontist and restorative dentist is essential to align biological limits with esthetic goals.
üëâ Helle-note: Veneers are not orthodontics‚Äîand without retention, they typically fail over time. The ideal path is: align first, veneer later, and secure results with solid long-term retention. That way, you deliver minimally invasive beauty that actually lasts.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q1097
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Are aligners suitable for bruxism patients?
synonyms: Can patients who grind their teeth use aligners?
Do aligners help or worsen bruxism?
Should bruxism patients have different retention?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners can be used in bruxism patients, but they require special planning and long-term protection strategies. Bruxism increases risks of faster wear, tracking issues, and long-term instability if not managed correctly.
Deprogramming effect ‚Äì With bite ramps, aligners can sometimes act as deprogrammers, reducing muscle hyperactivity by decreasing elevator muscle activity. This can temporarily relax the patients and protect the teeth. This may lead to the joints seating in CR and creating an anterior open bite that is to be handled afterwards (refinement and/or restorative treatment)
Risks ‚Äì Bruxism patients often wear through aligners faster, increasing the risk of poor tracking, posterior open bite, or fractured trays. Extra aligners or reinforcements may be necessary.
Retention strategy ‚Äì Post-treatment, retention is especially critical. These patients typically need both orthodontic and restorative treatment. Anterior- and canine guidance is critical and should be taken into consideration during treatment planning. An acrylic full-coverage splint is recommended for retention in combination with bonded retainers, as it keeps teeth in place, lasts much longer than aligners, and prevents enamel wear.
Alternative retainers ‚Äì For daytime or esthetic needs, aligner retainers may still be used, but should be combined with a nighttime acrylic splint for optimal protection.
Patient communication ‚Äì Explain to bruxism patients that aligners are not a substitute for splint therapy, but can be integrated into an overall protection plan.
üëâ Helle-note: Bruxism patients need extra attention‚Äîaligners can help, but they aren‚Äôt always enough on their own. Always combine with restorative reconstruction of the anteriors including proper canine guidance with immediate posterior disocclusion and anterior guidance in perfect balance with the incisors a strong retention protocol and a splint solution that protects teeth long-term. We‚Äôll help you design the right plan for even the heaviest grinders.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q1098
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: What about patients with existing prosthetics?
synonyms: Can aligners move teeth with bridges?
What if my patient already has crowns or implants?
How do prosthetics affect aligner planning?
answer_markdown:
A. Patients with existing prosthetics can be treated with aligners, but treatment must be carefully adapted since bridges and implants cannot move orthodontically. In some cases, prosthetic work must be modified or replaced to achieve an ideal outcome.
Implants ‚Äì These are ankylosed and completely immovable. They can, however, be used as anchorage points during treatment. Space closure across an implant site is not possible.
Fixed bridges ‚Äì Bridges act like splints, preventing orthodontic movement of the teeth they connect. Treatment planning must account for this, and in some cases, replacing or sectioning a bridge may be necessary.
Crowns ‚Äì Teeth with crowns can usually be moved if they have healthy periodontal support. Attachment bonding may be less reliable, but careful surface preparation improves success.
Restorative revision ‚Äì Sometimes existing prosthetics must be redesigned or replaced after orthodontics to achieve proper esthetics, occlusion, and function.
Occlusion planning ‚Äì Always evaluate whether keeping the existing prosthetics will compromise the final occlusion. If so, replacement should be planned as part of the overall treatment.
üëâ Helle-note: Prosthetics don‚Äôt have to stop aligner treatment‚Äîbut they do demand extra thought. Sometimes the only way to give patients the best smile and bite is to change or replace existing restorations. We can help you judge when to adapt the ortho plan and when to coordinate with restorative dentistry.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q1099
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Can aligners be used for trauma patients?
synonyms: Are aligners safe after dental trauma?
Can traumatised teeth be moved orthodontically?
When should I treat or refer trauma patients?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligners can be used in patients with a history of dental trauma, but only under very strict conditions. Periodontal stability and pulpal vitality must be confirmed before starting, and movements should be extremely light and conservative.
Periodontal stability first ‚Äì Never move traumatised teeth until healing is complete and tissues are stable. This may take months or longer depending on injury severity.
Avoid risky movements ‚Äì Do not attempt to move teeth that were directly involved in trauma or ankylosed teeth unless a specialist has confirmed safety. Excessive forces can accelerate resorption or destabilise the tooth.
Light mechanics ‚Äì Use very gentle forces and slower staging than in standard cases. Monitor mobility, vitality, and radiographs regularly and closely throughout treatment.
Referral threshold ‚Äì If there is any doubt about prognosis, or if trauma was severe (luxation, avulsion, root fracture), refer to an orthodontist for evaluation and management.
Patient communication ‚Äì Be clear that orthodontic treatment in traumatised teeth carries higher risks and may require compromises in outcomes.
üëâ Helle-note: Trauma cases are not for shortcuts. Always stabilise first, move carefully, and if you‚Äôre unsure‚Äîrefer. Patients will thank you for protecting their teeth instead of risking them.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH03:SEC15:spacing-and-crowding, MAO:TBD:q10100
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: How should I phrase requests using mm/¬∞ per stage and do-not-edit zones to avoid unintended global changes?
synonyms: How do I give precise instructions to aligner technicians?
What is the best way to communicate tooth movements?
How do I stop technicians from changing areas I don‚Äôt want touched?
answer_markdown:
A. Precision in communication is critical when working with technicians. Vague instructions often lead to unintended global changes in the digital setup. Always use exact values, define staging clearly, and protect areas you don‚Äôt want altered.
Be specific ‚Äì Use exact numbers: e.g., ‚ÄúClose 1.0 mm of space at 0.2 mm per aligner‚Äù or ‚ÄúTorque UR1 by 5¬∞ at 1¬∞ per stage.‚Äù Avoid general phrases like ‚Äúmove slightly‚Äù or ‚Äúreduce overjet.‚Äù
Define staging ‚Äì Specify the rate per stage (mm or ¬∞ per aligner) to ensure forces are realistic and predictable. This prevents the software from applying excessive movements too quickly.
Do-not-edit zones ‚Äì Clearly mark or state which teeth should not be altered. For example: ‚ÄúDo not change posterior occlusion from 14‚Äì17‚Äù or ‚ÄúKeep lower left quadrant untouched.‚Äù
Check technician edits ‚Äì Always review setups carefully to ensure instructions were followed. If technicians ignore instructions, reiterate with simple, unambiguous phrasing.
Consistency ‚Äì Use the terminology of the prescription form (each brand has its own standards). This helps technicians understand without needing clinical background.
üëâ Helle-note: Remember‚Äîmany technicians don‚Äôt have a dental background. They follow your instructions literally. The clearer you are with mm, ¬∞, and do-not-edit notes, the better results you‚Äôll get‚Äîand the fewer refinements you‚Äôll need.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q11101

question: Which terms or descriptions should I avoid to prevent misinterpretation?
synonyms: What‚Äôs the wrong way to write instructions for technicians?
Which words confuse aligner technicians?
How do I stop setups being misinterpreted?
answer_markdown:
A. Many communication errors come from vague or subjective wording. Since most aligner technicians don‚Äôt have a dental background, ambiguous descriptions lead to unpredictable or unintended results. Always use measurable, quantified instructions instead.
Avoid vague words ‚Äì Phrases like ‚Äúslight,‚Äù ‚Äúa little,‚Äù ‚Äúsome,‚Äù ‚Äúminimise,‚Äù or ‚Äújust a bit‚Äù are open to interpretation.
Be numerical ‚Äì Replace subjectivity with numbers: ‚ÄúClose 0.5 mm of space per side at 0.2 mm per aligner‚Äù or ‚ÄúTorque 5¬∞ at 1¬∞ per stage.‚Äù
Directional clarity ‚Äì Don‚Äôt just say ‚Äúmove forward‚Äù or ‚Äútip back.‚Äù Specify mesial/distal, buccal/lingual, intrusion/extrusion, and degrees or millimetres.
Global edits ‚Äì Avoid statements like ‚Äúimprove occlusion‚Äù or ‚Äúmake it look better.‚Äù These give the software too much freedom and often create unintended global changes.
Check outputs ‚Äì Even with precise language, always verify the digital setup matches your plan before approval.
üëâ Helle-note: Keep it simple and measurable. Technicians aren‚Äôt mind-readers, and they‚Äôre not orthodontists. If you want 0.5 mm, say 0.5 mm‚Äînot ‚Äúa little less space.‚Äù Clear language means fewer surprises and fewer refinements.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q11102
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: Should I give one complete set of instructions or send incremental changes?
synonyms: Is it better to send all instructions at once?
Do technicians handle stepwise instructions better?
How many requests can I give at a time?
answer_markdown:
A. In general, it‚Äôs more efficient to provide a single, complete set of instructions rather than sending multiple incremental changes. However, the reality is that aligner technicians have limits in both training and execution capacity‚Äîso your instructions must be clear, prioritised, and minimal.
Complete set preferred ‚Äì Submitting all planned changes in one go reduces back-and-forth communication and speeds up case approval.
Technician limitations ‚Äì Most technicians can realistically handle no more than 3 instructions at a time, and even then, often only 2 are followed correctly. Prioritise the most critical instructions first.
Complex revisions ‚Äì If more than 3 instructions are needed, break them into phases. Handle the most biologically or functionally important corrections first, then move on to esthetic or minor adjustments.
Clarity and hierarchy ‚Äì Phrase instructions in numbered order (1, 2, 3) and clearly mark ‚ÄúDo Not Edit‚Äù areas to avoid unwanted global changes.
Documentation ‚Äì Always double-check the resulting setup to confirm the instructions were actually implemented before approving.
üëâ Helle-note: Less is more. Don‚Äôt overwhelm technicians with long lists‚Äîthey won‚Äôt follow them. Pick your top two priorities, make sure they‚Äôre done right, and only then move to the next adjustments. We‚Äôll help you filter what matters most so you don‚Äôt waste time fixing what should have been simple.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q11103
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: How do I ensure technicians don‚Äôt alter areas I haven‚Äôt commented on?
synonyms: Why did technicians change teeth I didn‚Äôt mention?
How do I protect areas I‚Äôm happy with?
What are do-not-edit zones?
answer_markdown:
A. Technicians will often make unintended global changes if you don‚Äôt explicitly protect areas you are satisfied with. To prevent this, you must clearly define and communicate ‚Äúdo-not-edit zones.‚Äù
Use software tools ‚Äì Most 3D aligner platforms allow you to lock or mark areas that should remain untouched. Always use these features.
Mirror in written notes ‚Äì Repeat the ‚Äúdo-not-edit zones‚Äù in your written instructions: e.g., ‚ÄúDo not alter occlusion 14‚Äì17 and 24‚Äì27‚Äù or ‚ÄúLower arch from 34‚Äì44 stays as is.‚Äù
Limit scope ‚Äì Be very specific about which teeth or segments are protected. Broad phrases like ‚Äúdon‚Äôt change posterior‚Äù invite errors.
Check after revisions ‚Äì Even when zones are marked, review setups carefully‚Äîtechnicians sometimes ignore partial instructions.
Consistency pays ‚Äì Using the same simple format in every case reduces misinterpretation over time.
üëâ Helle-note: Never assume technicians will ‚Äúleave it alone.‚Äù If you don‚Äôt lock it, they will move it. Protect your good work with do-not-edit notes‚Äîthis one habit can save you hours of frustration and unnecessary refinements.

question: What if my own 3D adjustments get overwritten by technician changes?
synonyms: Why did the technician remove my edits?
How do I stop technicians from undoing my work?
Can I protect my 3D controls?
answer_markdown:
A. It‚Äôs common for technician revisions to overwrite your 3D adjustments unless you explicitly protect them. To avoid losing your work, always request ‚Äúlocked edits‚Äù and compare versions before approval.
Locked edits ‚Äì Ask the aligner company to preserve your clinician-made 3D changes as locked movements. This prevents technicians from overriding them during revisions.
Do-not-edit notes ‚Äì Reinforce your edits in writing: ‚ÄúDo not change my adjustments on teeth 13‚Äì23 torque‚Äù. Written instructions plus locked edits give double protection.
Compare versions ‚Äì Request a side-by-side view between your edit version and the technician‚Äôs revision. This makes it easy to confirm your changes were preserved.
Check critical teeth ‚Äì Pay special attention to teeth you‚Äôve rotated, torqued, or staged yourself‚Äîthese are the most likely to be overwritten.
Escalate if repeated ‚Äì If technicians consistently ignore locked edits, escalate to clinical support or switch to a planning service that respects clinician input.
üëâ Helle-note: Think of your 3D edits as gold‚Äîthey‚Äôre based on your diagnosis, not a technician‚Äôs guess. Always protect them with locked notes and double-check revisions. If this keeps happening, let us help‚Äîwe make sure your plan stays your plan.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:TBD:q11105
_Needs anchor mapping_

question: What‚Äôs the best way to combine 3D edits with written notes so they support each other?
synonyms: Do I need to repeat 3D edits in writing?
How can I make sure technicians follow my adjustments?
What‚Äôs the safest way to document changes?
answer_markdown:
A. The most reliable way to ensure technicians follow your treatment plan is to combine 3D edits in the software with clear written notes. Redundancy is not wasted effort‚Äîit dramatically reduces errors and misinterpretations.
Double entry = double safety ‚Äì Apply your edits in the 3D software, then repeat them in writing (with mm/¬∞ per stage if possible). If one channel fails, the other backs it up.
Reinforce do-not-edit zones ‚Äì Mark segments as ‚Äúlocked‚Äù in the 3D controls and also write: ‚ÄúDo not alter posterior 16‚Äì26 occlusion.‚Äù
Numbered instructions ‚Äì Structure your notes clearly: 1. Close 0.5 mm spacing 12‚Äì13 at 0.2 mm/stage. 2. Torque UR1 by 5¬∞ at 1¬∞/stage. This helps technicians process your plan step by step.

question: When is it better to request a completely new plan instead of modifying the old one?

question: Which tooth movements have the lowest predictability, and how should I stage them?
synonyms: What are the hardest movements with aligners?
Which movements often fail?
How should I plan difficult tooth movements?
answer_markdown:
A. Some tooth movements are inherently less predictable with aligners. The key is to recognise them early, stage them more slowly, and support them with auxiliaries when necessary.
Extrusion ‚Äì Particularly anterior extrusion is unpredictable. Staging must be slow and supported by attachments, elastics, or auxiliaries. Posterior extrusion is even more difficult and often unreliable.
Rotations ‚Äì Canine and premolar rotations >15¬∞ are difficult to achieve. Use large attachments, careful staging, and expect refinements.
Torque control ‚Äì Especially with scalloped-trimline systems. Consider horizontal attachments, stiffer aligner materials, or auxiliaries like power arms and TADs.
Mandibular molars ‚Äì Among the least predictable teeth to move. True translation (bodily movement) of lower molars is almost impossible with aligners. Don‚Äôt attempt to distalise them, and don‚Äôt attempt mesialisation to close extraction spaces‚Äîif anything they will tip, not translate.
General principle ‚Äì Stage these movements with smaller increments, ensure strong anchorage, and use auxiliaries when predictability is low. Avoid relying on ‚Äúovercorrection‚Äù‚Äîthat principle belongs to fixed appliances, not aligners.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt beat yourself up if mandibular molars or stubborn canines don‚Äôt move the way the software promised‚Äîit‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs the biology and the limits of aligners. Focus your efforts where predictability is high, and use auxiliaries or alternative appliances for the rest.

question: For demanding root control/torque, when should I consider higher retention/force strategies?
synonyms: How do I achieve reliable torque with aligners?

What makes root control more predictable?
answer_markdown:
A. Torque and bodily root movements are among the least predictable with aligners, especially in systems with scalloped trimlines or softer materials. In these cases, you must consider strategies that increase retention and force delivery.
Straight trimlines ‚Äì Systems with straight gingival margins provide better force transfer because they grip the tooth more effectively than scalloped designs.
Stiffer materials ‚Äì Rigid aligner plastics can deliver and maintain torque forces more consistently, especially in anterior teeth where precision is critical.
Attachment design ‚Äì Horizontal attachments or torque-specific auxiliaries improve aligner grip and help control the root rather than just the crown.
Auxiliaries ‚Äì In challenging cases, consider power arms or TADs to apply force closer to the centre of resistance. This significantly improves predictability.
Clinical thresholds ‚Äì Demanding root control should not be attempted with aligners alone if the discrepancy is large (e.g., >10¬∞). In such cases, hybrid approaches or referral may be required.
üëâ Helle-note: Torque is where aligner systems really show their limits. Don‚Äôt expect miracles from plastic alone‚Äîif you want true root control, you‚Äôll need better retention, stiffer materials, and sometimes extra tools. We can help you judge when aligners are enough and when you‚Äôre fighting biology.

question: How do I prevent posterior open bite during treatment?
synonyms: Why do aligner patients develop posterior open bite?
How can I avoid posterior open bite with aligners?
What staging mistakes cause posterior open bite?
answer_markdown:
A. Posterior open bite (POB) is a common complication in aligner therapy, often caused by staging errors, insufficient IPR, or neuromuscular factors. Prevention requires careful planning and monitoring.
Settling phases ‚Äì Include staged aligners at the end with minimal movements to allow natural occlusal settling before retention.
IPR accuracy ‚Äì Inadequate interproximal reduction is one of the most frequent hidden causes of POB. If insufficient space is created, teeth can‚Äôt fully seat, leaving posterior contacts open. Using a calibrated IPR system (e.g. Dentatus) dramatically improves predictability.
Neuromuscular factors ‚Äì Patients with reduced mandibular angle or hyperactive masseters are prone to clenching, which can also contribute to POB.
Monitoring ‚Äì Track occlusion at each visit. Early detection of posterior clearance allows corrective adjustments before the problem escalates.
üëâ Helle-note: Posterior open bite isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúbad luck‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs often preventable with proper IPR and staging. And if it does happen, don‚Äôt panic. Ask us‚Äîwe‚Äôll help troubleshoot and adjust your plan so you don‚Äôt waste time repeating the same mistakes.

question: What‚Äôs the best way to capture a reliable bite?

answer_markdown:
A. A reliable bite registration is critical, as errors here will compromise the entire digital plan. Aligners are not articulators, so don‚Äôt expect the software to resolve discrepancies between CR (centric relation) and MIP (maximum intercuspation).
Clenching during scan ‚Äì Prior to scanning the bite, ask the patient to clench the posterior teeth firmly. This prevents unintentional protrusion during bite registration.
Leaf gauge or deprogrammer ‚Äì These tools can be used to eliminate habitual shifts and capture a repeatable centric relation when indicated.
CR vs MIP ‚Äì CR registration can be valid under specific conditions, but aligner software cannot simulate functional occlusion. Never rely on a digital ‚Äúbite jump‚Äù‚Äîit won‚Äôt happen clinically.
Check setup first ‚Äì Always verify the bite in the digital setup as the very first step. Compare it with your clinical photos. If the bite doesn‚Äôt match, stop, rescan, and correct it before proceeding.
Documentation ‚Äì Clearly note any discrepancy between CR and MIP in your prescription form to reduce technician guesswork.
Clinical consequence ‚Äì If you plan a case on a false bite, the entire treatment outcome will be compromised, regardless of how polished the digital plan appears.
üëâ Helle-note: Bite errors are the silent killers of aligner cases. Double-check early‚Äîcompare scans with photos‚Äîand don‚Äôt waste time planning if the bite is off. Fix it first, or you‚Äôll fight problems all the way to refinements.

question: When should I request additional radiographic views (CBCT/OPG)?
synonyms: Do I need more x-rays before aligner treatment?
When is CBCT necessary?
When should I order an OPG for aligner patients?
answer_markdown:
A. Additional radiographic imaging is essential for safe aligner treatment planning. While CBCT should only be used when clearly indicated, an OPG combined with selective intraoral radiographs is considered mandatory.
OPG (panoramic x-ray) ‚Äì Always recommended as a baseline. It provides an overview of tooth positions, root angulations, missing or impacted teeth, and general bone levels.
Supplemental periapicals ‚Äì Intraoral x-rays of the mandibular and maxillary incisors should always be added, since these areas are often blurred or unclear on an OPG. This is crucial for diagnosing root morphology, bone levels, and early pathology.
CBCT ‚Äì Reserved for specific cases: impacted, ectopic, or ankylosed teeth, trauma, pathology, or when 3D assessment of bone volume/root positions is essential.
Software caution ‚Äì Some aligner systems now overlay CBCT data to simulate tooth movement in bone. These are graphic visualisations only and cannot model bone remodeling. They should never be used as the sole basis for treatment planning.
Clinical risks ‚Äì Over-reliance on CBCT-driven software may lead to false confidence, over- or underdiagnosis, and inappropriate treatment decisions.
üëâ Helle-note: An OPG + selective intraorals (especially incisors) is your baseline safety net. CBCT can add value in special cases, but don‚Äôt let flashy software visuals fool you into making risky plans. If in doubt, ask‚Äîwe‚Äôll guide you on when extra imaging is truly necessary.

question: How do I set maximum per-stage movement for difficult tooth movements?
synonyms: What‚Äôs the safe limit per aligner?
How much can I move teeth per stage?
What are realistic staging values?
answer_markdown:
A. Clear aligner therapy depends heavily on respecting biological limits. Exceeding safe thresholds is one of the most common reasons for tracking loss and refinements. Difficult movements like torque, rotations, and bodily translations must be staged conservatively.
Translation (bodily movement) ‚Äì Broad guideline: ~0.25 mm per aligner. Faster staging often results in tipping instead of true bodily movement.
Rotations ‚Äì 1‚Äì1.5¬∞ per aligner is a safe benchmark. Canines and premolars are more resistant, sometimes requiring auxiliaries.
Torque ‚Äì Around 1¬∞ per aligner is realistic, especially in scalloped-trimline systems. Horizontal attachments, stiffer plastics, or auxiliaries may be required for reliable root control.
Extrusion ‚Äì Among the least predictable. Stage in very small increments and support with attachments or elastics.
Individual variation ‚Äì These numbers are broad recommendations. Each tooth responds differently: some can tolerate slightly more, others far less. Always consider tooth morphology, periodontal support, and anchorage before setting staging values.
General rule ‚Äì When in doubt, slow down. Smaller increments improve predictability and reduce the need for refinements.
üëâ Helle-note: Think of staging values as guidelines, not gospel. Every tooth has its own limits‚Äîand your patient‚Äôs biology always sets the final rules. Better to move slower and succeed than push too hard and lose control.

question: How do I use overcorrections or virtual power chains effectively?

answer_markdown:
A. Overcorrection is a concept from fixed appliances and should not be relied upon in aligner therapy. Aligners don‚Äôt deliver forces the same way brackets and wires do, and overcorrections often result in biologically unrealistic plans. Instead, focus on controlled mechanics and consider virtual power chains when closing spaces.
Avoid overcorrection ‚Äì In aligner cases, planning beyond the intended endpoint rarely improves predictability and often leads to tracking problems.
Virtual power chains ‚Äì Useful in the final stages of treatment to assist with space closure and to improve contact tightness between anterior teeth.
Movement limits ‚Äì Power chains can help close small residual spaces, but they cannot compensate for poor staging earlier in the plan.
Midline corrections ‚Äì Can be supported with virtual chains in selected cases, but always check anchorage balance to avoid unwanted side effects.

üëâ Helle-note: Forget about overcorrection‚Äîit belongs to fixed braces, not aligners. Focus instead on solid staging and use virtual chains as a finishing tool, not a magic fix. If in doubt, we‚Äôll help you integrate them without risking stability.

question: How do I decide between expansion vs IPR for crowding?
synonyms: Should I expand or do IPR for crowding?

What‚Äôs safer: expansion or stripping?
answer_markdown:
A. The decision between expansion and interproximal reduction (IPR) depends on arch form, periodontal support, and long-term stability. Both methods can provide space, but their biological consequences differ.
Arch form ‚Äì Expansion should only be done if it respects the patient‚Äôs natural arch form. Excessive expansion risks relapse and periodontal compromise.
Periodontal support ‚Äì Thin buccal bone plates limit how far you can expand. In cases with reduced support, IPR is usually safer and more stable.
IPR advantages ‚Äì Preserves arch form, reduces black triangle risk when performed correctly, and creates space without moving roots outside bone housing. Use a calibrated system (e.g. Dentatus) to ensure accuracy.
Expansion advantages ‚Äì Can improve smile esthetics in narrow arches and reduce the need for enamel reduction. Works best in younger patients with thicker alveolar bone.
Clinical strategy ‚Äì In many cases, a combination of slight expansion and IPR gives the best balance of esthetics, biology, and stability.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt think of expansion and IPR as either/or‚Äîthey‚Äôre tools you can combine. The key is respecting biology. Too much expansion or sloppy IPR will both come back to haunt you. We‚Äôll help you plan the right mix so your patient gets stable, esthetic results.

question: How do trimline design choices influence treatment?
synonyms: What‚Äôs the difference between straight vs scalloped trimlines?
Do trimlines affect retention?
Which trimline design gives better force control?
answer_markdown:
A. Trimline design has a significant effect on aligner biomechanics, particularly in terms of retention, force transfer, and torque control. The choice between straight and scalloped trimlines is not just cosmetic‚Äîit impacts predictability.
Straight trimlines ‚Äì Extend beyond the gingival margins, increasing undercut engagement and improving retention. This allows for stronger force delivery and better torque expression. Particularly important for root control and demanding movements.
Scalloped trimlines ‚Äì Follow the gingival margin closely. They are often more comfortable and esthetic, but provide significantly less retention and weaker force transfer. Attachments become more critical when using scalloped designs.
Biomechanical consequences ‚Äì With scalloped trimlines, aligners tend to lose grip more easily, making torque and intrusion especially unreliable. Straight trimlines distribute forces more evenly across the tooth surface.
Clinical trade-off ‚Äì Comfort vs control: scalloped = more esthetic/comfortable but less powerful; straight = less esthetic but biomechanically superior.
System choice ‚Äì Since different aligner systems use different trimline designs, you must adapt your planning strategy to the system‚Äôs inherent strengths and limitations.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt underestimate trimline design. It can make or break the predictability of your treatment. If you‚Äôre working with a scalloped system, expect to compensate with attachments and auxiliaries. If you want maximum control, straight trimlines will give you an edge.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH04:SEC07:tooth-movements-definitions, MAO:TBD:q12119

question: What are the differences between common aligner plastics (PETG, TPU)?
synonyms: Does aligner material matter?
Which aligner plastic is better?
What‚Äôs the difference between PETG and TPU?
answer_markdown:
A. The choice of aligner plastic directly influences force delivery, comfort, and tracking stability. While both PETG and TPU are widely used, they behave quite differently in the mouth.
PETG (Polyethylene Terephthalate Glycol-modified) ‚Äì A stiffer material that delivers stronger initial forces and maintains its shape better over time. This improves torque control and predictability but can feel less comfortable for the patient initially.
TPU (Thermoplastic Polyurethane) ‚Äì A more flexible material that adapts closely to tooth surfaces and is often perceived as more comfortable. However, it loses force more quickly, leading to reduced effectiveness if aligners are not changed frequently.
Force decay ‚Äì PETG retains force levels longer, while TPU tends to soften and lose force within a few days. This difference affects staging intervals and overall predictability.
Clinical impact ‚Äì For demanding movements (torque, root control, bodily translation), PETG generally performs better. TPU may be preferable for sensitive patients or simpler cases.
Trimline interaction ‚Äì Stiff PETG combined with a straight trimline maximises control. Flexible TPU with scalloped trimlines offers comfort but weakens biomechanics significantly.
üëâ Helle-note: Material matters more than most doctors think. PETG gives you power, TPU gives your patient comfort. Always consider case complexity when choosing a system‚Äîsometimes comfort costs predictability.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH04:SEC07:tooth-movements-definitions, MAO:TBD:q12120

question: What are best practices for bonding attachments to ceramics or veneers?
synonyms: Can I bond aligner attachments to veneers?

What protocol ensures durable bonding on porcelain?
answer_markdown:
A. Bonding to ceramic surfaces (veneers, crowns) requires strict pretreatment and adherence to protocol. Enamel bonding rules don‚Äôt apply‚Äîceramic must be chemically and mechanically prepared for predictable attachment retention.
Surface preparation ‚Äì Sandblast and etch with hydrofluoric acid for 30 seconds (‚ö†Ô∏è only intraoral-approved HF acid). This step is highly caustic‚Äîuse strict safety measures.
Isolation ‚Äì Always place rubber dam. Avoid any contact of HF with patient soft tissues or your team.
Rinse and dry ‚Äì Remove HF completely with copious water, then dry thoroughly.
Silane application ‚Äì Apply a silane coupling agent. We recommend Monobond Plus (Ivoclar) since it maintains stability longer than many silanes, which often expire within a week of opening. Allow silane to dry fully.
Bonding agent ‚Äì Apply a conventional bonding resin or adhesive. Light-cure according to manufacturer‚Äôs instructions.
Composite attachment ‚Äì Build the attachment using flowable or conventional composite, then light cure. Ensure the attachment shape matches your digital plan.
üëâ Helle-note: Bonding to ceramics isn‚Äôt something to shortcut. With the right protocol, attachments can last just as well as on enamel. Without it, they‚Äôll pop off almost immediately. If you‚Äôre unsure, ask‚Äîwe‚Äôll help you through the exact steps so you don‚Äôt waste chair time.

question: Which cases are safe for 7-day changes, and when should I keep 10‚Äì14 days?

answer_markdown:
A. Aligner change intervals should always respect biology and patient compliance. While some cases may eventually be managed with a 7-day protocol, you should never start a new treatment with 7-day changes. Bone remodeling begins only after the first few weeks, and rushing early stages is a recipe for tracking loss and refinements.
Start protocol ‚Äì Always begin with 14-day intervals. The first 4 weeks are critical for periodontal ligament and bone adaptation. This is also when you bond attachments, perform initial IPR (if accessible), and begin to assess patient compliance.
Re-evaluation ‚Äì After 4 weeks, evaluate fit, tracking, and compliance. If everything is ideal, some cases may transition to 7-day wear for simple movements (minor tipping, mild crowding, small rotations <10¬∞).
Keep 10‚Äì14 days ‚Äì For complex biomechanics (torque, bodily translation, extrusion, large rotations), periodontally compromised patients, or if compliance is questionable.
Tracking check ‚Äì Poor fit is an immediate sign that wear time is too short. Always slow down rather than push forward.
Clinical pearl ‚Äì Shortcuts early in treatment always backfire. Respect biology at the start‚Äîif you lose control here, refinements and wasted chair time are inevitable.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt gamble on speed. Start slow (14 days), let biology adapt, and only then consider acceleration. Patients will thank you when their treatment stays on track instead of dragging out with endless refinements.

üìñ Reference: MAO ‚Äî MAO:CH04:SEC07:tooth-movements-definitions, MAO:TBD:q12122

question: How do I triage fit issues or tracking loss?
synonyms: Why don‚Äôt the aligners fit?

answer_markdown:
A. Tracking loss is one of the most common clinical challenges in aligner therapy. Early detection and systematic troubleshooting help avoid unnecessary refinements and wasted chair time.
Check seating ‚Äì Use chewies or other seating aids to confirm whether the aligner can fully engage. If it doesn‚Äôt seat even with pressure, there‚Äôs a true tracking problem.
Evaluate attachments ‚Äì Inspect whether attachments are intact, correctly shaped, and still active. A missing or worn attachment can compromise specific movements.
Contact points ‚Äì After the initial 4 weeks, ensure floss glides easily between approximal contacts. Tight contacts may block movement despite aligner pressure.
Compare with digital plan ‚Äì Always check the ClinCheck/setup to see where movements have deviated. Identify whether the problem lies in staging, insufficient IPR, or compliance.
Action steps ‚Äì
If mild: extend wear time, reinforce patient compliance, add chewies.
If moderate: use clinical workarounds such as cutouts, buttons with elastics, or sectional auxiliaries.
If severe: a refinement with new scan and updated plan is usually unavoidable.
üëâ Helle-note: Tracking problems are normal‚Äîit doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôve failed. What matters is recognising them early and choosing the right fix. Sometimes a simple chewie works, sometimes you need a full refinement. We‚Äôll help you judge the fastest way back on track.

question: What‚Äôs the best workflow for mid-treatment refinements when attachments fail or rotations stall?
synonyms: How do I restart when treatment stops working?
What should I do if attachments break?
How do I handle stubborn rotations?
answer_markdown:
A. Mid-treatment refinements are common, especially when attachments debond or difficult movements (like rotations) stall. A structured workflow ensures you regain control efficiently without losing patient confidence.
Rescan & new records ‚Äì Always begin with updated IO scan and photos. This captures the current position accurately and resets the foundation for a reliable new plan.
Redesign attachments ‚Äì Evaluate whether existing attachment shapes and positions were sufficient. Consider larger or differently oriented attachments. In stubborn cases, place attachments on both facial and lingual surfaces to improve force application.
Staging adjustments ‚Äì Slow down. Reduce per-stage increments (e.g. ‚â§1¬∞ rotation, ‚â§0.2 mm translation) to improve predictability.
Auxiliaries ‚Äì Use cutouts, buttons, and elastics to assist rotations or uprighting where aligners alone struggle. These ‚Äúhacks‚Äù often save time compared to multiple failed refinements.
Patient compliance ‚Äì Confirm aligners are worn 20‚Äì22 h/day. Poor compliance often masquerades as poor biomechanics.

question: How do I stage movement around implants or pontics?
synonyms: Can I move teeth next to implants?

What‚Äôs the rule for aligners and implants?
answer_markdown:
A. Implants are ankylosed and cannot move. When planning around implants or pontics, the goal is to move natural teeth predictably while protecting restorative space and emergence profiles.
Implants are fixed ‚Äì Never attempt to move an implant. Always mark them clearly in your prescription and in the software so technicians don‚Äôt try to shift them.
Uprighting adjacent teeth ‚Äì Teeth adjacent to implants can often be uprighted or torque-controlled to optimise restorative space. This improves long-term stability and esthetics.
Pontics ‚Äì Maintain pontic space carefully. Ensure roots are parallel and the space width suits the planned prosthetic restoration. Avoid excessive tipping of adjacent teeth into the pontic site.
Emergence profile ‚Äì Plan tooth movements to allow a natural emergence profile for the final restoration (bridge, crown, or implant). Crowding or poor angulation near pontics can compromise restorative outcomes.
Clinical tip ‚Äì Sometimes auxiliaries or sectional mechanics may be needed to upright roots effectively near a fixed implant.
üëâ Helle-note: Always treat implants and pontics as fixed anchors in your digital setup. They don‚Äôt forgive sloppy planning. If you‚Äôre unsure, let us help set the stage so the restorative work looks and functions beautifully.

question: How do I manage bruxism or high-function patients?
synonyms: Can aligners be used in bruxers?
How do I plan aligner treatment for patients with tooth wear?
What precautions for high-function cases?
answer_markdown:
A. Bruxism and high-function patients present unique challenges in aligner therapy. They often have significant tooth wear, stronger-than-average muscle forces, and higher relapse risk. Management must be interdisciplinary and realistic.
Diagnosis first ‚Äì Always identify bruxism early. Tooth wear is irreversible, so treatment should be seen as ortho-restorative, not purely orthodontic. Teeth won‚Äôt ‚Äúgrow back‚Äù with aligners.
Treatment planning ‚Äì Plan for final restorations (veneers, onlays, crowns) if tooth structure is significantly compromised. Aligners can reposition teeth, but restorative dentistry is needed to rebuild worn surfaces.
Aligner material ‚Äì Consider using thicker or stiffer aligners in these patients. Standard aligners may fatigue faster under excessive occlusal load. Consider using anterior bite ramps to relax the muscles and seat the joints.
Retention strategy ‚Äì Long-term retention is critical. Combine fixed retainers with removable retainers or splints to protect against relapse and further wear.
Night guard/splint therapy ‚Äì Post-treatment, prescribe a full-coverage acrylic splint (rather than only aligner-type retainers) to protect both restorations and natural teeth.
üëâ Helle-note: Bruxism cases aren‚Äôt simple aligner cases‚Äîthey‚Äôre a mix of orthodontics and restorative dentistry. If you try to ‚Äújust align,‚Äù you‚Äôll fail both esthetically and functionally. We‚Äôll help you plan the ortho-restorative pathway so your patient‚Äôs new smile actually lasts.

question: What precautions are needed for periodontally reduced dentitions?
synonyms: Can aligners be used in periodontitis patients?
What‚Äôs different when treating reduced periodontium?
How do I move teeth with bone loss safely?
answer_markdown:
A. Orthodontic treatment of periodontally reduced dentitions is possible but requires careful control of forces, staging, and monitoring. These patients are more biologically fragile, and standard mechanics can quickly lead to loss of support if precautions are not followed.
Force levels ‚Äì Apply lighter, more continuous forces. Reduced bone support lowers resistance, so teeth move with less pressure.
Movement staging ‚Äì Slow down. Use longer aligner intervals and smaller per-stage increments to reduce trauma.
Biomechanical considerations ‚Äì The center of resistance and center of rotation shift apically when bone levels are reduced. This makes it harder for aligners to control root movements, especially torque. Straight trimline systems may struggle if undercuts aren‚Äôt fully blocked out, as patients may otherwise find aligners difficult to remove.
Hygiene & stability ‚Äì Treatment should only proceed if periodontal disease is stable and hygiene excellent. Poor plaque control is a direct contraindication.
Monitoring ‚Äì Schedule more frequent recalls, including probing and mobility checks.
Interdisciplinary approach ‚Äì Coordinate closely with a periodontist for risk assessment and long-term maintenance.
üëâ Helle-note: These patients can often be treated almost like ‚Äúnormal‚Äù cases‚Äîif their periodontium is stable. The key is gentleness: lighter forces, slower staging, and closer monitoring. Always fix the foundation first, or everything else fails.

question: How do I coordinate aligners with restorative sequences?

How do I plan tooth movements with restorative work?
answer_markdown:
A. Aligner therapy and restorative dentistry can complement each other, but timing is critical. The general principle is to move teeth into an ideal position before placing final restorations‚Äîthis preserves tooth structure and optimises long-term esthetics and function.
Orthodontics first ‚Äì Always stage aligner treatment before definitive restorations. This reduces the need for aggressive tooth preparation and allows restorations to be thinner and more conservative.
Provisional restorations ‚Äì Use provisionals during orthodontics when esthetics or function must be maintained (e.g. in worn dentitions or fractured teeth). These can be adjusted as teeth move.
Digital smile design ‚Äì Plan the final restorative outcome with digital mockups to guide tooth movements. This ensures orthodontics and prosthetics work toward the same goal.
Vertical dimension of occlusion (VDO) ‚Äì If restorative plans involve increasing VDO, carefully integrate this into aligner staging and ensure occlusion is tested provisionally before committing to final restorations.
Team approach ‚Äì Close collaboration between restorative dentist and orthodontic planner is essential for sequencing and stability.
üëâ Helle-note: Ortho-restorative cases are some of the most rewarding, but also the most complex. Let orthodontics set the stage so your restorative work can shine. We‚Äôll help align the biomechanics with the final smile design, so the patient gets the best of both worlds.

question: What are effective retainer protocols after aligner treatment?

answer_markdown:
A. Retention is lifelong. Teeth tend to relapse toward their original positions if not properly stabilised. A structured retainer protocol reduces relapse risk and protects treatment results.
Our protocol ‚Äì
Last aligner: 3 months, 22 h/day
Following 3 months: 16 h/day
Lifelong: 8 h/night
Fixed retention ‚Äì Essential after significant rotations (especially canines) or expansion. We recommend bonded retainers: first premolar to first premolar in the lower arch, and canine to canine in the upper arch, often combined with a removable retainer.
Aligner-based retainers ‚Äì Retainers fabricated from the last aligner stage may allow natural settling into a more stable occlusion, since the clinical endpoint rarely matches the digital plan 1:1.
Material considerations ‚Äì Retainers supplied by aligner companies are usually more precise and durable compared to in-office Essix retainers.
Clinical warning ‚Äì Aligner material does not allow for settling and introduces long-term occlusal separation (plastic between teeth). For this reason, we often combine fixed retainers with removable acrylic plates (Jensen or Hawley) for improved function.
üëâ Helle-note: Retention is not an afterthought‚Äîit‚Äôs half the treatment. Patients must understand it‚Äôs lifelong, and you as a clinician should plan retention just as carefully as active movement. We‚Äôll help you choose the right mix so your results last.

question: What are the main differences between aligner systems?

answer_markdown:
A. While all major aligner systems are designed to move teeth, they differ in materials, design, and workflow. These differences don‚Äôt make one system universally ‚Äúbetter‚Äù but do influence biomechanics, comfort, and how you as a clinician plan and execute treatment.
Plastic material ‚Äì Some systems use stiffer plastics (e.g. PETG) that provide stronger, longer-lasting force. Others use more flexible plastics (e.g. TPU) that feel more comfortable but lose force faster. This impacts staging intervals and movement predictability.
Trimline design ‚Äì Straight trimlines engage undercuts better and improve torque/retention. Scalloped trimlinesare more comfortable and esthetic but weaker biomechanically, making attachments more important.

question: Is one aligner system more effective than another for complex movements?
synonyms: Which aligner is best for torque and extrusion?
Do some systems handle complex cases better?
Does brand matter for difficult movements?
answer_markdown:
A. No single aligner system is inherently superior for complex cases. Effectiveness depends far more on biomechanics, material properties, and clinician planning than on the brand name. That said, certain design features do make a difference in how well difficult movements can be executed.
Material stiffness ‚Äì Stiffer plastics (e.g. PETG) maintain force levels longer, making them more effective for torque, bodily translation, and root control. Softer plastics (e.g. TPU) lose force faster and are less suited for these demanding movements.
Trimline design ‚Äì Straight trimlines provide better retention and transfer of forces, essential for torque and extrusion. Scalloped trimlines, while more comfortable, often underperform in complex biomechanics without heavy reliance on attachments.
Torque & extrusion ‚Äì These are among the least predictable movements across all systems. Stronger retention designs (straight trimlines + stiff plastics + strategic attachments) give the best chance of success.
Clinician factor ‚Äì Case setup and staging remain the biggest determinants. Even the ‚Äúbest‚Äù material and trimline design fail if the plan is unrealistic.
Auxiliaries ‚Äì For complex biomechanics, auxiliaries like elastics, buttons, power arms, or TADs are often needed regardless of system.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt expect the brand to solve complex biomechanics for you. What matters is knowing when to slow down, when to add auxiliaries, and when a system‚Äôs design supports you‚Äîor works against you. We‚Äôll help you judge that balance so your plan stays realistic.

question: Do different brands use different plastic materials, and does that matter?
synonyms: Do aligner brands use the same plastic?
Which material is best for aligners?
Does aligner plastic affect treatment?
answer_markdown:
A. Yes‚Äîdifferent brands use different plastics, and it matters a lot. The material directly affects force delivery, comfort, and the predictability of complex movements. Choosing between stiff and flexible plastics isn‚Äôt about ‚Äúbetter or worse,‚Äù but about matching biomechanics with patient needs.
Stiffer plastics (e.g. PETG-based) ‚Äì Deliver stronger initial forces, hold shape longer, and improve control of torque, bodily translation, and root movements. Ideal for complex biomechanics, but may feel less comfortable to patients in the first days of wear.
Flexible plastics (e.g. TPU-based) ‚Äì Adapt closely to tooth surfaces and are often perceived as more comfortable. However, they lose force faster, which reduces predictability of torque, extrusion, and root control unless aligners are changed more frequently.
Force decay ‚Äì Stiffer materials maintain active forces longer (useful for 10‚Äì14 day wear schedules), while flexible ones fatigue quickly (better suited to shorter change intervals if compliance is excellent).
Trimline interaction ‚Äì Material performance is amplified or reduced depending on trimline design: stiff plastic + straight trimline = maximum retention and control; flexible plastic + scalloped trimline = comfort but weaker biomechanics.
Clinical choice ‚Äì Complex movements demand stiff plastics. For simpler cases or highly compliance-sensitive patients, flexible materials may suffice.
üëâ Helle-note: Plastic isn‚Äôt just plastic. The wrong material choice can make your life harder than it needs to be. Comfort is nice, but control is critical. We‚Äôll help you balance both so you don‚Äôt compromise predictability.

question: How does trimline design (straight vs scalloped) affect treatment?
synonyms: Which trimline works best?
Do scalloped edges improve comfort?
Does trimline choice change biomechanics?
answer_markdown:
A. Trimline design is one of the most important‚Äîand often overlooked‚Äîfactors influencing aligner biomechanics. It determines how well the aligner grips the teeth, how effectively forces are transferred, and how predictable difficult movements like torque or extrusion become.
Straight trimlines ‚Äì Extend beyond the gingival margin, engage undercuts, and significantly improve retention. They deliver stronger, more consistent force and allow for better torque control, root movement, and extrusion. They may be slightly less esthetic and can feel bulkier to patients, but the biomechanical benefits are substantial.
Scalloped trimlines ‚Äì Follow the gingival contour closely. They look more natural and feel more comfortable, but they provide less retention. This makes them heavily reliant on attachments to achieve movements that straight trimlines can deliver on their own.
Biomechanical impact ‚Äì With scalloped designs, torque control, bodily translation, and intrusion are notably less predictable. Straight trimlines distribute forces more evenly across the tooth surface, improving predictability of complex movements.
Clinical choice ‚Äì For simple esthetic alignment, scalloped trimlines may be sufficient. For demanding biomechanics, straight trimlines combined with stiff plastic are strongly preferable.
üëâ Helle-note: Don‚Äôt underestimate the trimline. It‚Äôs not just a design choice‚Äîit changes how well your aligners work. If you‚Äôre struggling with torque or retention, the trimline may be the hidden culprit.
